reviews.reviewTitle: It is also my favorite so far
reviews.reviewText: I've been home roasting and grinding my coffee for about 18 years. This is my third burr grinder. It is also my favorite so far. The first was a Krups that used a volumetric dosing. It was made of plastic, built up static and made for messy grinding and imprecise doses. I stopped drinking expresso after I got fed up with the Krups and switched to the Bodum Bistro which served me well, but was lousy for espresso grinds. The hopper was also too small because I roast a full pound in my Behmor 1600 and like putting the whole drum into hopper. The Breville has a one pound hopper which is removable. The grind seems uniform and it's easy to use. I don't use the plastic vessel they provide because I either grind straight into a portafilter or into a glass tumbler because static is less of an issue. Don't see why Breville included a sealable container for ground coffee when any rational coffee lover would NEVER use ground coffee that had sat in a container (sealed or otherwise). I considered the Baratza Encore and Virtuoso. This seems to sit somewhere in between, although I like Breville's look more. I calibrate the timed dosing with a small scale I bought from Harbor Freight. While I realize different coffee varietals and roast would change, the variation does not bother me. I get wonderful Espresso and Vacuum Pot coffee from this machine.

reviews.reviewTitle: Excellent grinder, best in its price range
reviews.reviewText:
My husband and I were looking for a good grinder that could do both espresso and french press for under 200 bucks. We first tried the Rok coffee grinder. Bad idea, messy, intrinsically defective, major design flaws, sprayed out grounds in a cone shape with the open end pointed down (messy as f***), just all around a bad idea. The Smart Grinder Pro was our second attempt at getting a good grinder in this price range. So how did it work out?

Overall, the smart grinder pro is the best bang for the buck.
-I love the digital readout for the grind, it makes it very easy to reproduce previous good grinds.
-The timing function is super useful for handling dispensing the grounds.
-The anti-static chamber is excellent, I have noticed no static cling issues whatsoever with this grinder.
-The portafilter fittings are also a nice touch and make it very easy to grind straight into the portafilter for my Gaggia classic. Easily cuts 3 minutes off of the time it takes to make my espresso.
-The hopper design is nice as well, its airtight and fits more than enough beans. The grind quality is consistent, I usually grind at around a 9 on the main grind settings with 6 on the macro adjustment on the burr itself (this is the default setting). I love being able to pull the hopper off of the grinder and change out or refrigerate the beans.
- Supposedly Breville is great when it comes to replacement parts availability.

Now for the flaws or I should say annoyances. Most of these aren't too bad but I'll mention them in the interest of full disclosure.
-This unit is slower than the Baratza Sette 270. The Sette gets your espresso in the portafilter in ~4 seconds, this machine takes ~17.5 seconds.
-Another issue is that although there is a pause functionality on the grinder, it isn't really useful because the damn thing resets the timer after about 10-15 seconds. This is annoying if you're grinding and then redistributing the grounds in a portafilter. Not the worst thing in the world but it's something that should (and definitely can) be fixed by the manufacturer with just a simple software tweak so that the timer at least takes one or two minutes before resetting. Still, you can just hit the start button again until there's enough coffee there for your liking. If you do drip coffee, you won't even notice it.
- Not the end of the world but a lot of the "metal" is just plating. It still feels sturdy and doesn't hurt the functionality (or bargain) of the machine but again, full disclosure. I knew this going in and it hasn't been an issue.
- For espresso, you don't have a *huge* amount of room to work with as far as grinds but I've found that I have enough. I started with overly fine grinds and was able to dial in fairly quickly. For some machines that need finer grinds, it may be an issue. Like I said, with the gaggia classic, I haven't had issues.
- I haven't tried this myself but supposedly this machine suffers in the course grind range (french press) but is more than adequate for french roast.
-Having lived in apartments with two prong outlets, I'll mention that this device has a three pronged plug. Not a problem for most people but just something to be aware of.

All in all, a great grinder, good choice for espresso. Would buy again.

reviews.reviewTitle: Read My Lips, Get This Grinder!
reviews.reviewText: I own a Saeco Via Venezia Espresso Machine. I had a cheap Saeco bean grinder that was a messy nightmare (donated, best for French Press, maybe). My espresso always tasted burnt and the grind was always uneven. I thought it was my machine or water temp, but it wasn't. It's always the grinder. Respect the beans! Shell out the dough for a quality grinder like this one. It costs almost as much as the espresso machine itself, but with this grinder my espresso is ground fresh every time and the shots are always Belissimo-Perfecto-Magnifico (I'm doing that Italian 'kissing fingertips and tossing away' gesture). I set this baby to grind setting 12 and 15 second grind using the easy to read LED settings. Tune your grind however you like! You wont regret this purchase.

reviews.reviewTitle: So far So Good (make that Great)
reviews.reviewText: Once I got my Breville bambino espresso machine I realized to do it right I had to have a good grinder. I looked at YouTube's, saw reviews and chose to get the Breville grinder. I have been very pleased! I have the ability to make the adjustments to my specifications, to grind how long and how coarse or fine. To grind the exact amount for a 2 shot espresso or a one shot espresso. Machine is small compared to some and the price was very acceptable.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great grinder until you have to fix it
reviews.reviewText: I've had this grinder for not quite a year, under moderate use, and I've been very happy with it UNTIL it started jamming just today. I did some research on the web and it turns out that there's a plastic part deep within the mechanism that normally wears out within about a year. There's actually a guy who's posted a video that explains the problem and shows step-by-step how to fix it. (Look for "breville smart grinder pro jamming problem" on YouTube.) But the fix requires disassembling the entire unit. As for the part, Breville apparently doesn't sell spare parts, so this guy has designed a 3D printed replacement part that may be better than the original, and you have to order it for about $25 from a site called shapeways.com. Sooo...if you're handy, if you have the right tools and if you don't mind having to disassemble your grinder periodically, this is a really great coffee grinder. Otherwise, I guess you can send the grinder in to Breville every year or so and pay about $100 every time to have them fix it. OR buy a Baratza and forego some of Breville's nifty automated features.

reviews.reviewTitle: Excellent grinder, Very easy to use and clean
reviews.reviewText:
I had a simple Braun disc grinder that I misplaced during our Kitchen renovation, and finally got around to researching and replacing it. This Breville "Smart Grinder Pro" looks sharp and has many more features than I will ever use, but so far it's been terrific. It's not static free, as implied by some of the reviews, but it's not bad with only a little sticking to the sides of the grinds container easily knocked off with a tap.
I mostly do French Press, and the Coarsest grind setting is still a little fine by default, however you can easily adjust the range by rotating the outer burr (see instruction manual). I think it's setup by default for espresso users, so they can't be faulted for setting the default range a little fine.
The grind is uniform, and moderately quick (not too fast to get hot!) and the coffee is excellent! A great upgrade.

reviews.reviewTitle: First review. It could change (Electronics failure)
reviews.reviewText:
Out of the box, I give my first experience with the Breville Smart Grinder Pro one star because there is an issue with the electronics. Most of the complaints I see about the Smart Grinder pro is the impeller failing after 6 months to a year and complaints about the grind being extremely fine even on the coarsest settings. But I haven't seen reports of the failure my machine experienced.

Most people researching the Smart Grinder Pro as a possible purchase (And you should before you buy any product) understand how to set the functions of the machine. After following the instructions out of the box, i insured the burr was fully seated and snapped into place. Then the same with the bean hopper, fully seated and snapped into place. Then I put a few beans in the hopper for a test grind. The little cursor that marks the grind setting immediately began running back and forth up and down the scale. This action caused a constant change in grind time. Fearing I had failed to set the removable burr fully in place, I stopped it, cleaned the machine completely and started over. Same result, as soon as I turn the machine on to grind, the the grind setting cursor runs wild up and down the scale. Two more attempts to get it right and I decide the electronics came busted on this machine, whether a loose wire somewhere or a bad circuit board in the control panel.

I started the process of returning the grinder and am sent to Amazon Tech Support, where I explain to a very nice person (Arlene) my problem with the machine. After talking her through exactly what happened, this nice person set up a replacement to be sent. I give Amazon and the nice Arlene 5+ stars for being so courteous and helpful. I hope the electronics failure of my first Breville Smart Grinder Pro is not a common problem.

I will update this review after I receive the replacement grinder and test it out for a while.

4/4/19 update: The replacement arrived promptly and thus far works as advertised. Still working through the grind settings, but that is an operator issue. Hopefully The Smart Grinder pro will have a healthy life span. 4 star for prompt replacement by amazon and a working grinder. Now to see how well it performs.

6 month update- 7July19:
Still delighted, have not experienced any problems

I had to buy a new grinder because I need one that will produce a fine enough grind for a non-pressurized espresso. After some research I could only find three below $250 that can do this. This one, for $180, and the Baratza Virtuoso, for $140 and the Compresso Infinity. Reading the reviews for the Baratza it appears that you first have to get instructions from the internet on how to adjust the shims on the burrs to get very fine, (what the …?) This alone is worth the extra $40 for this one.

After opening the box I was impressed with the build quality and attractive appearance. It produces consistent and even grinds, that alone is worth the $180. There are 3 features that surprised me. The first being the LCD panel, I figured this was unnecessary and perhaps cheesy, well it works great and is very useful. The second is the grind time control. I was thinking this would be a poor substitute for a built-in scale, but that is not the case. I sometimes keep it simple and make my espresso with a pressurized filter, and since grind fineness is not so critical, I use grind size setting 15, it just so happens that this size happens to grind my medium roast beans at 1 gram per second (I have a digital kitchen scale to establish this) so to make pressurized espresso I set the grind to 15 and the timer to 14 seconds and I consistently get 14 grams of perfectly ground beans! I am still playing with what grind works best for non-pressurized so I haven’t yet established what time I will need to get my 18 grams. Bottom-line, the timer is a perfectly adequate substitute for a built-in scale. The third feature is the option to dispense grinds directly into your portafilter. I figured this would be useless as it would be messy and with all the grinds left on the counter I would end up with fewer grams in the filter. Wrong again, it works great! It puts 99.9% of the grinds in a neat mound in the middle of the filter, much better than I can do by hand. With the grinds in a neat mound in the middle of the basket I can tamp them down without spilling any grinds (again, something I can’t do when putting grinds in the filter by hand)!

Between even and consistent grinds, including the very fine grind size needed for non-pressurized espresso, the timer and the ability to dispense grinds directly into the filter, this is a fabulous grinder at this price and I think can hold it's own with machines at twice the price. Some complain about uneven grinds at the coarse setting. If all you want is French press coarse grinds then you don’t need an espresso focused grinder, save yourself money and buy the Cuisinart DBM-8 for only $40.

Finally, the issue of reliability. All I can say for sure is that mine came in great working order, and while I have not had it long enough to vouch for long-term reliability, since it is solid and well-built I see no reason that it won’t be reliable. But if you are still worried, consider this. If you look at the reviews for most grinders and espresso machines you will see that about 2/3 rds of the scores are 5’s and 4’s, with between 15% to 20% being 1’s, primarily bitching about reliability and warning you not to buy whatever it is. Well in this case ¾’s give it a 5 or 4 and only 12% are 1’s. I see this as a testament to it’s build quality and reliability … just sayin'.

If I experience issues in the future I will post an update.

reviews.reviewTitle: I thought I'd like the timed grind function
reviews.reviewText:
I home roast and enjoy experimenting with various brewing methods and roasting profiles. A key component to the "prefect" cup is grind. like many before me I found this grinder does not do a very course grind, not what I call course. I'd call it a heavy medium at best (strike one). I've always weighed grounds to cup so I thought I'd like the timed grind function, however the grind volume was inconsistent. Maybe I'm just a little to anal here but having up to a gram and a half over or under my target was just irritating (strike two). Strike three is the stupidly short power cord. Without an extension cord or power strip there is no locating the grinder anywhere other than right at an outlet.

The up side, all the grinds were very consistent, it's easy to use, well built and easy to clean.

Here's what I'd like to see, change the timer to a scale, add an additional medium to course top burr and a longer stow-able power cord.

Yes, it was returned

It's AMAZING! This is our second Breville grinder. We purchased our first one five years ago, and loved it - after five years of lots of grinding nicely, we got an odd bag of espresso beans that had some little stones in the bag with the beans. The company stated that it was sorry but because it is a natural product (like beans), things like stones are a possibility but not a probability. We do believe that the grinding burry MAY have been slightly damaged or at the very least, dulled by the rogue stones. Replacement burr's are available from Breville, but they have also discontinued the model that we had purchased five years ago.
Which brings us to this newer model being a new star on our counter top. The new machine (comparing it to the old model) is pretty much whisper quiet. It also has a grind timer. When I make an espresso, I like to double tamp the grind in two stages. Fill it half way, then tamp, then fill it the next way and tamp again. The timer set at 10.5 seconds for each pulse works perfectly for the double porta-filter that goes with our Breville Infuser espresso machine. The machine gives a fantastic personal taste grind. The settings alone might take a while to dial in to your preferences. For me, thankfully I just set it at about the same settings for my old grinder and managed to get pretty lucky by only having to tweak it a bit.
Parts are available online at Breville as far as outer parts (the grinder itself), and not the internal gears. With the way appliances go bad of late, (it seems that nothing can last longer than four or five years), I'm more than pleased that this grinder is doing my morning grind for me. I truly believe that the days of an appliance lasting a lifetime is LONG gone, which means that if I must replace more often, I will at the very least make sure that I get the best replacement possible. It's a purchase that I'd make again!

reviews.reviewTitle: Works fantastic and looks good - Best value in this price range
reviews.reviewText:
I'm always amazed at how no product can get consistent reviews and this product fits that bill with a certain % hating it, well, all I can say is these haters are crazy. For this price range it's a great choice.
It looks great, is extremely easy to use, is fairly quite (no burr grinder is super quite), has a sturdy build quality, and grinds coffee perfectly to your exact specifications. This model always makes the top 5 burr grinder rankings and I now understand why. I originally had the much less expensive cuisinart burr grinder and it did a good job but nowhere close to this machine in terms of grind accuracy and the ability to go very fine plus it was a messy operation with that machine (coffee grinds always spilling). If you love coffee spend the extra bucks and get this machine!

reviews.reviewTitle: The Best! And I didn't come to that conclusion easily!
reviews.reviewText: I was hesitant to review a product that I've owned for less than a week, but if my opinion changes, I will come back with an update. Let me preface this review by saying that I am comparing this burr grinder to what I considered to be the gold standard: The KitchenAid Pro Burr Grinder. If they still sold it, I'd have bought another without hesitation. I couldn't even find replacement burrs to have it rebuilt...which brought me to my search. Reluctantly. I felt like I was cheating on a lover, but the day had come. After reading way too many reviews and feeling way too much ambivalence, I chose this Breville Smart Grinder Pro. I went into it KNOWING that I'd be disappointed, because nothing could compare, right? Well if you've read this long and wonder when I'm going to get to the actual review part, here it is: this grinder is amazing. It performs like my KitchenAid did when I first bought it! The precision, the low temperature, the perfection of the grind, the ease of operation, the looks? If I could give it more than five stars, I would. Initially I felt disappointed that the hopper and bin weren't glass...but guess what? I'll never break that and have to purchase a replacement again! Something that happened to me twice with the delicate glass bin. I thought the glass gave it a more solid professional look, but I'm totally pleased with the appearance of this grinder. I didn't think it was possible...but I prefer it to my old faithful. I said my goodbyes to my KitchenAid, with a tear in my eye, but now I am all smiles and filled with joy as I drink what is quite possibly the best cup of coffee I've ever ground. If anything changes, I'll update this review, but for now I'll just give five stars and say: THE BEST. Simply, the best.

reviews.reviewTitle: After over a month I am perfectly happy with my grinder
reviews.reviewText:
After over a month I am perfectly happy with my grinder. After experimenting I have the exact grind coarseness (48) for my machine (Technivorm), the exact amount of beans (3 level scoops) for the half pot I make, and the exact grind time (20 seconds). So I just hit one button and the machine does the rest. (I may have to re-calibrate when I change the nature of the beans I grind, I realize.)
Slight static charge leaves a dust on the receptacle lid, which I blow off over the sink, but a few taps of the jar on the heel of my hand causes all the grounds to leave the jar itself. I will probably never submerge the jar or use chemicals to clean to protect its slick interior.
If using the jar, carefully screw on the top all the way but not overly tight. If you do, you can push the jar just as far back in the machine as goes and you will feel it just barely "seat". If the open hole is dead center left/right it will be under the shoot from the grinders and one of the white scale markings will be perfectly centered facing you. When I place the jar just as described/designed, I have no spilling outside the jar whatsoever.
Before I fully appreciated this jar placement, I was accidentally clogging the shoot from the grinders and the machine locked down. I stopped it before there was any damage and first looked to clear the grinders, but when that did not do the job I found that the opening below was full of packed ground coffee, which released with a toothpick. Back in business and no issues in the weeks since.
Grinder noise not a problem, though I would not call it quiet. If is high-pitched and not overly loud. The machine is large relative to many, but I would not trade. Espresso people will have to check other reviews, as I don't grind for any coffee machine but my own.

We have a higher end home espresso maker which requires a very fine grind. Burr grinders are hands down the way to go for grinding and even the lower end, high quality grinders are around $700. Coffee shop grinders are $3k - $5k. For around $200 this machine is remarkable. The digital time adjustment and very fine grind ability are perfect the 2-4, double espressos we pull a day. Having the ability to grind directly into the portafilter is genius! We have had the machine for about two months and are still thrilled with it's performance. Assuming it lasts a couple of years with daily use I'll be ecstatic.

reviews.reviewTitle: Grinder is not reliable. Amazon and Breville do not take responsibilities to fix the issue!!!
reviews.reviewText:
Pro:
I liked that it worked ONLY for the first month of use.

Cons:
Amazon cannot refund the purchase eventhough the issue happened less than 30 days guarantee period and Breville does not take the responsibility to fix the issue either!!!

1. It heats up very quickly;
I just use it to grind light roasted 20 gram coffee beans at a coarse grind of 50.
After the grind, I can feel my grinder turning quite warm and burnt coffee smell came out of the grinder.
This grinder heats up very easily.

2. Furthermore after a month of using, the grinder just would not grind anymore!
The whole grinder is still working, as in the LCD panel, the hopper, etc,
At first I thought the grinders are jammed by residue from previous grinds,
So I cleaned them up, but still nothing.
When I click the START button, nothing happens, just the stopwatch on the LCD panel kept on running, no sound, no grinding.
I have contacted Breville and they are yet to have a say on this.

I purchased this product when our 5 year old burr grinder died. Knowing the impact on the taste of coffee a good grinder can have, I was nervous about every product I viewed. I was stunned by the differences between our old grinder and the Breville. It truly makes fresh ground coffee a no brainer. Once you find the setting you prefer for your coffee, it's as simple as pushing a button to have the perfect amount of coffee ground for you every time, with NO MESS! The bean storage bin eliminates the need for an additional storage container, so even net counter space is less, with NO MESS. In addition to that repeatable formula, we find we're using less beans than in the past for the perfect cup of coffee for us. It's not as loud as our old machine, but it's still not what I'd call quiet, but it grinds our perfect pot in 22 seconds and I don't have to stand there. We've only had the Breville for a month, but we're as pleased as we were on day 1. We're currently drinking drip coffee only, so haven't tried it for espresso yet. I don't think you can go wrong with this machine. Did I mention there's NO MESS?

I ordered this grinder together with espresso infuser machine. It seemed good value proposition plus it compliments the espresso machine. After several weeks of use thinks changed. I noticed that I have to readjust its grind settings quite often (I used Lavaza Super Crema), almost every other day. It is not consistent enough to be used for espresso. By the time I realized that this is not an espresso grinder it was too late to return to Amazon. Amazon CS connected me with Breville. Breville rep suggested me using the double wall filter instead to compensate for grinder inconsistent output... Why buy a grinder then? I also noticed that the motors power is not up to task, I can hear its speed varies during 16 seconds of grinding. Again if you are looking for espresso grinder, look elsewhere. You don't need to go through the same trouble. I am stuck with it now, not a happy espresso drinker.

For us, this is worth the price. We drink a lot of coffee - a LOT of coffee - and after our upgrade to an espresso maker, we were grinding it all by hand. As my review for the Java Press manual grinder states, there is a large time commitment with the manual grinders; with more than two people, we are easily talking 10-15 minutes. The Breville Smart Grinder, on the other hand, gets us excellent espresso grounds for 4+ shots in 30-45 seconds. The espresso size grinds range between very fine (almost the size of powdered sugar) to about what I was getting out of the manual grinder (about the size of small sand). It is a touch loud, but less so than the steam wand on the espresso machine itself. Besides, who cares about talking BEFORE you've had your coffee anyway?!?

Now, is it with the ~$200? We said no for a very long time and were still happy enough. But once we had some extra Christmas money left, this was well worth the treat instead of, say, a new stainless steel pot. If you are looking for kitchen gadgets and have the budget for it, this is well worth your money.

reviews.reviewTitle: This grinder works great when compared to all that I've used
reviews.reviewText: I use this for esspresso, French press, percolator, and drip. I have worked in a few coffee shops and operated a few different industrial grinder models as well as many of the home editions. This grinder works great when compared to all that I've used. There may be a grinder more suitable for the home out there but I haven't used it yet. For the price I would love to give this 4 stars because sometimes the grinds catch on top of the included catch container. I like an imaculate kitchen and think that design could work a little better. However when I consider that the process of grinding coffee is inherently messy I've never used a cleaner or more easy to clean grinder. Also considering it is just a coffee grinder it would be nice to spend less. I gave it 5 stars because I just haven't found a better grinder priced and intended for home use. Regardless I'm almost certain I won't need to buy a grinder for at least 20 years. Taking into account TVM this is a good investment. Before you buy (or not) remember this value includes a machine that is easy to use, very versatile, keeps coffee fresh, and allows you to achieve the quality some beans need to exract their taste. If you are a simple coffe drinker this may not be the investment for you. If you have fun with coffee, take it serious, experiment often, or expect consistancy than this product would work for you. I've used it for 4 months now sometimes more than twice a day. I will update this if anything to note happens.

This is an absolute fantastic coffee grinder until about a year of use. Then a part within the machine wears down and it renders all of the exact grinding features useless. Breville does not sell a replacement part to correct this problem, and if you google the 820, 800 or 600 series hundreds of people have posted that this problem exists across all models of this grinder. If you want to drop $200 a year on a grinder this one will be great for you. We bought this as a present multiple times for family before knowing about the issue, soon enough theirs will stop working as well.

reviews.reviewTitle: Best coffee we've had from a home style grinder!
reviews.reviewText: I purchased this after a lesser grinder stopped working. I wanted something durable and more reliable than the typical made in china offerings that die after 6 months or a year. The unit is very robust, solid, well designed and properly engineered. The accessories are of equal quality and build. The grind is very uniform with little dust, no larger granules and little waste. As mentioned above, the taste is actually much better. This surprised me as I did not think the quality of grind had that much affect on taste. The price bites a bit for a small countertop appliance. However, it delivers and lives up to the advertisement hype.

I love this thing. Before, I would grind my beans every few days. Not a huge deal but it meant taking out my old grinder, grinding them, putting them in an air tight container, and putting everything back. Then every morning scooping the ground coffee into the coffee maker filter. This machine has simplified all that and saves me a little time every morning. While I'm cleaning out the coffee pot I put the filter under the grinder outlet and press a button (2x actually, 1x to turn on and 1x to grind....why?). Presto, freshly ground coffee done once I'm done cleaning out the pot. I haven't messed with the time or grind setting since day one. What a wonderfull little device. Breville never disappoints (I have three of their products)!

This is my second one. The first was ruined when a bag of coffee beans had a small nail in it. That messed up the burrs a little. It still worked and I used it that way for several years but it was getting old and wanted to replace the burrs but the company no longer sold them. What they had was for this newer design so I decided to replace the whole thing. This new design is actually nicer to use.

I say ALMOST perfect because I am not at all interested in espresso and it is designed to accept the variously sized espresso "dosers" (I think they are called) and that makes for a bit of fussiness putting in and taking out the cup that catches the grinds for normal coffee making. There is a loose (by design) part that tends to pull out with the cup requiring you to reseat it almost every time. It's not a big deal but rankles!

reviews.reviewTitle: Who Knew A Bean Grinder Could Make Such A Difference??
reviews.reviewText: This replaced a Maestro Mini coffee bean grinder that stopped working after a decade of almost daily use. Initially, I was very skeptical about paying such a substantial amount of $$ for a coffee bean grinder for strictly home use, but holy cow!! I can't even put into words the difference this grinder has made to our coffee AND we're using fewer coffee beans, which in turn saves money (not much, but every little bit helps!). One of my favorite features of this bean grinder is that I can grind directly into a portafilter, paper filter, or the container included with the unit. While it is an expensive appliance, I have to say at least for us it's worth the investment.

This thing seals the deal. I am now a Breville believer. A self-proclaimed coffee snob, I fully admit my use is limited to the much less picky method of auto drip coffee. So read elsewhere for important info on particle consistency and whatnot. But this thing is by far my favorite burr grinder I’ve used. After initial tweaking (as in the first two pots, max) I push a button to grind and direct my attention to the rest of the brewing process. It quite neatly spits out the perfect amount of my fresh roasted addiction about the time I have my water and basket ready. But my favorite thing is that it is amazingly quiet for a coffee grinder. The Breville folks seem to think of everything. Read up on the features yourself. I don’t baby it at all, and it is working like new 4 months in. I’ve got mine paired with the Breville Precision Brewer, which is also really great, but I did not intentionally set out to love on Breville. Every bean and roast I’ve fed it have come out perfectly pleasing, nothing like my experiences with other machines.

What can I say, I love this grinder. I am new to coffee roasting and grinding and I first purchased the cuisinart but was immediately dissatisfied with it. Just plain messy. Every time I used it I had to clean up after myself and I swear it burned my beans. This Breville has just about every feature I could want, its EASY to dial in the exact amt of coffee I want for a single cup (yes, I drink filtered coffee) and just plain does NOT make a mess. Easy to clean the burrs (hint grind minute rice through the grinder to absorb excess coffee oils). Compared to other grinders I feel this give me the best bang for my grinder dollars AND its not ugly as so many other grinders are. Love it.

My 20 year old Kitchen Aid Burr grinder was giving up so I had to find a replacement. After buying a Breville toaster recently I immediately looked at that brand grinder. I have only had this grinder for about 2 weeks but so far am really happy with it. I do have one complaint that I am surprised Breville hasn't figured out. When I bought it I saw that there were many settings for fine - coarse grind but they really need to have it a bit more coarse for those of us that drink pour over and make cold brew. After a call to support I learned how to set the burr to the most coarse setting and when I set the dial to the most coarse it comes out right. Breville needs to cover these methods of coffee making in their instructions but they emphasize espresso. I will definitely keep this grinder and will enjoy it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Cup O’ Joe with a side of noise
reviews.reviewText: Ok, some history. I started out manually grinding my own beans, only to find that it was a bit of a chore. Hence my purchase of a good conical burr grinder such as our Breville here. The pros far outweigh the cons with this piece of equipment, but it could be better. Firstly, the noise can be a bit annoying. My wife has made fun of the “whirring” that it makes on multiple occasions and that is from upstairs in the bedroom. Secondly, the settings, while easy to change, are not as dialed in as I would expect with all the digital circuitry included. I honestly love just being able to come down, hit the button and wait a couple of seconds for my coffee to grind. Would definitely recommend.

reviews.reviewTitle: I really love the way the coffee grinds are totally consistent
reviews.reviewText: I really love the way the coffee grinds are totally consistent. But I was surprised that the most course setting is still smaller than my old grinder (which was very inconsistent). The red color is a great match with other appliances and looks great on the counter. I also love the fact that the hopper hods a pound of coffee and the cover easily seals out the air (like a Tupperware lid, only easier to seal.) I also lve the way the grounds receptacle is also seal-able and the shelf it sits on can be removed for cleaning. The shelf actually snaps back in because it is magnetic. The only thing I don't like is the fact that the grounds do tend to not all go into the receptacle. Some will adhere to the top of the receptacle and some above on the delivery chute. But it is easy to clean up, especially if you remove the receptacle and just reach up and wipe the chute, then pull the shelf out and dump the remaining loose grounds in the sink.

Worked maybe two weeks and the sweeper arm broke down. Attempted to fix it...found that parts were not available. I have always bought Breville products and this is the first one that just completely let me down. Shame on you Breville for making such a beautiful product that only works as a door stopper--and for making me buy a Baratza Virtuoso+ to replace it two weeks after buying it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Grinds the beans the way a blade grinder couldn't
reviews.reviewText: When I was searching for a Burr Grinder to replace a blade grinder, I read all the reviews for the major burr grinders. It was a toss up between Cuisinart and Breville. Some of the Breville reviews scared me a little, however, I decided that since I already owned Breville products and they have worked well for me that I bought the Breville Burr Grinder. Well, I am happy to say that it works great. Easy to clean … a lot easier than my blade grinder. If you READ the instruction, the grinder will do whatever you want. I have even adjusted the top Burr to make a more coarse grind. I can only say that the Breville Grinder was worth it

The quality of the grind is excellent—we saw an improvement in flavor over our old cheap grinder. But the design is flawed such that beans don’t always flow as they are supposed to, and at least half the time we don’t actually get the amount of grind requested. The machine has no warning system to cause it to stop when it can’t pulk down beans. This results in grinding coffee taking significant time and requiring manual measuring. Not what I expected for a product at this price level.

After 1 year, it’s garbage. Unable to reliably grind coffee even after trying every ring setting on the burr. Motor runs but can’t process beans. Thought we were buying a premium product, we won’t buy again.

My husband is the barista around here. He is very fussy about his coffee. We had another burr grinder that just wasn't working all that well. The grind was inconsistent. Beans that were more oily clogged up the grinder. But the Breville Smart Grinder is a winner. The grind is consistent and it is a quieter appliance. He's very impressed! And that means more coffee for me!

reviews.reviewTitle: All adjustments are available for the perfect cup of joe.
reviews.reviewText: It works. This grinder is exactly what I expected. Easy to get an exact amount of properly ground coffee. The timer should be set to the number of seconds needed to give the user the desired weight of coffee. I set the timer to 8.8 seconds to provide about 18 grams of ground coffee. I also use a very course ground setting which works for me.

I did tons of research on grinders before purchasing the Breville and I will admit I was hesitant to spend so much money on something to grind my coffee.

I love coffee... I mean I LOVE coffee.

So the urge was strong and very real to have this glorious piece of machinery to assist me in feeding my addiction. Let's face it, at the end of the day money gets spread around and when you think about other less fun things that money could go toward like water bills, electric bills... food, it's a significant commitment to drop this kind of cash on something that does one thing--grind coffee.

But let me tell you... it does that one thing with unparalleled excellence. In my entire kitchen there is not one appliance I am more proud of than this Coffee Grinder. It's worked flawlessly through extensive use. I love the fact that it is completely serviceable. The hopper can be removed if you want to swap out your beans. It's also nearly endlessly configurable for all your various coffee needs. I appreciate the heft and overbuilt nature of the appliance as well--it's like a Volvo in that sense.

My only complaint about this product is that the container for the grounds is plastic so it gathers static and the chaff from the beans gets married to the sides of the container. Not a huge deal--no one wants to drink chaff water anyway.

The grinder has been used for over one and half years. Haven't had any problems with it grinding. It still works as excellent as the first day. I would suggest to uses Grindz to keep the burrs clean of any oily residue and to keep it in tip-top shape. I've use coffee beans that were very oily to dry. The only problem is that really dry beans become statically charged which gets everywhere. The spout to the cup that the coffee grinds into doesn't have a complete seal which would prevent this kickback. So the best solution is to not use overly dry beans so the cleanup becomes crazy difficult.

Although our old Breville grinder died after 4 years of about four double shots daily, we love how this grinder dispenses a fast and accurate grind every time. We replaced the old one with this new model and enjoy the new feature where you can adjust the precise seconds of grind so that the portafilter fills exactly, per that particular bean. We've gone with Breville for all of our coffee/espresso needs and have been quite impressed.

reviews.reviewTitle: Wow - who knew coffee could TASTE this good?
reviews.reviewText: I had a Cuisinart before this. Make that 3 - every one of them would last a couple of years and then die and I kept replacing them. When the most recent one died, I decided it was time to put on my big boy pants and buy something that is better made. I was hoping for something more reliable - but I never guessed how much better the coffee would taste. There is simply no comparison. I simply did not know that a coffee grinder would make such a difference in flavor. I can't say how this grinder will hold up over time, but if it lasts as long as my Breville espresso machine, I'll be happy.

I do not yet know about the durability of this unit, however, it does a good job for the cost. I have a naked portafilter and this grinder produces adequately fine and uniform grinds to use it perfectly. It is a vast improvement over every other grinder that I have owned. I love the ability to grind directly into the portafilter. This makes the grinder much cleaner to use than most grind and dump grinders. Also, it is quieter than my previous grinder(s). All-in-all, I recommend this grinder. I will revisit this review in awhile to address durability and cleaning issues.

I love this! Our coffee has never tasted better. The only downside is it's pretty messy and while it's easy to clean - I hate having to clean it every time. But because of the cost associated with the item - I really make a valiant effort to do clean it almost every time.

Side note: We use a Ninja coffee maker and the setting just above the espresso grind (I think it's 32). With doing so we have to use a paper filter instead of the filter that came with the ninja... which really we had to do that anyway because grounds got into the coffee and I don't like to chew my coffee. With this setting, the coffee is super super smooth!

reviews.reviewTitle: Good grinder easy to use. More difficult to obtain coarse settings
reviews.reviewText:
We use this grinder daily and had used a previous product from anther manufacturer for french press and drip coffee pots. This grinder replaces the older grinder that finally broke.

It is easier to get finer expresso grinds with the Breville grinder. The product is very fine and consistent. Despite adjusting the internal settings as directed I still cannot get the coarser grind I want for french press ordrip coffee, although the grind that I am getting produces acceptable drip coffee. The grind in my drip system is coming out as small kosher salt sized flakes. So the lesson learned with the Breville is that experimentation will be needed to fine tune your grind. The good news is that the controls allow that experimentation.

Set the internal dial to 10 and the LCD to 30. It still completely chokes my Breville espresso machine, even with the lightest tamp just to flatten the surface of the coffee. This is ridiculous. I tried calling Breville and kept getting this "If you don't want to wait on hold, press 2 and enter your call back number". That was 3 hours ago and still no call back. It's not looking too good right now. The grinder may find its way back to Amazon if I don't hear back in a couple of days.

I researched this grinder along with countless others and narrowed it down to two. I decided to buy this one because of all reviews online and I am certainly glad I did. It's sleekness, easy to use total customize able control is what separates this from its competitors. I started grinding my own coffee recently and wow the uniformity of the cut truly makes all the difference! Love the product and brand! :)

reviews.reviewTitle: Very fine grind good for espresso but too fine for drip to french press.
reviews.reviewText: Great looking range but it seems to go from medium fine at coursest setting to very very fine at fine setting. Would be good for espresso to turkish press. Too fine for drip to french press. The finer grind for drip may be ok once I figure out how much coffee per cup to set it for. Still a work in progress.

reviews.reviewTitle: The flavor of cigarette butts and charred coffee. A poor grinder.
reviews.reviewText: The grinder functions very well. This should get it high marks, but it destroys the flavor of the coffee beans, which is its primary task. We have used a Baratza Encore and Maestro Solis for years to grind our beans. The flavors are always subtle, rich and varied based on coffee bean variety. We used this product for a month and a half, hoping that all the bells and whistles would be worth it. They all work great, but the coffee, day after day, variety after variety, roaster after roaster, tasted either burn and like cigarette butts. We sought to return it, but our good-faith gesture in trying many varieties of coffee to make sure it was the grinder and not bad beans took us outside of the return window. We finally purchased another Baratza Encore and the delicious, warm and subtle flavors have returned. The grind on this coffee simply isn't good: it shreds the bean terribly and must warm it excessively in the process. I do not recommend this unless you enjoy the flavor of cigarette butts and charred coffee.

reviews.reviewTitle: Drip, press or expresso - perfect every time!
reviews.reviewText: This Breville Grinder not only met but beat every expectation I ever had when I ordered it. It is simple to use and very versatile in its settings. Some coffee grinders are good for expresso but not drip and others vice versus. This grinder is perfect for either. My son drinks drip coffee and immediately ordered one after trying mine. I drink expresso and it makes perfect grounds for it. By perfect, I mean the grounds for whatever setting you try are just that - uniform and perfect. If you love to grind your coffee, it will be hard to beat this grinder - especially for the price.

reviews.reviewTitle: My Favorite After Trying Several Over the Years
reviews.reviewText:
I've tried several grinders over the years, and this is by far my favorite. I only use it for fresh ground drip coffee (none of the espresso modes), so it may be a bit advanced / expensive for me, but I like it enough to write a review.

It's simple, not as noisy as others, no mess, and no static in the container when pouring out grinds. No power switch -- it goes to sleep and wakes on any button push. It maintains settings, and I don't need to fiddle with it. It's fairly quiet (my older ones sent the dog running & crazy). It doesn't make a mess (I no longer have grinds all over the counter). The container empties easy into my filter basket without much left behind (no static cling so far). I use 30 seconds for 8 cups, with 45 grind setting. It makes a very nice bold cup of coffee using Starbucks whole bean house blend. It was easy to dial back the setting from the default 45 seconds for 8 cups, which made very intense coffee -- too intense.

I've previously had a Cusinart (VERY noisy, clean but some jar static, not the best grind) and Bodum (noisy, always messy with static & grinds everywhere, decent grind). This one is the most expensive, but my favorite. I took the rubber stopper off the grind jar / catcher lid and always leave the jar on the machine. It holds in place with a magnet, and the tray below it comes out for easy cleaning if needed (I haven't had to do that, because zero mess or spilled grinds after a couple weeks' use). Recommend!

reviews.reviewTitle: Amazing value, grind options are endless.
reviews.reviewText:
Great value and definitely grinds so fine I’ve chocked my Pavoni several times. The only downside I have so far is that the grind does clump more so than it would on a more expensive machine. Not sure why exactly, just does. I have a little wisk that I use to solve the issue. Also done like the plastic portafilter holders, they are a bit flimsy; but they do the trick and the magnets are a nice feature.

Wish list.... add a scale and I’d be in heaven.

I’d buy again. In fact buying one as a gift for a friend who needs a better grinder for his Ascasso.

We bought this about a month ago and it is dreamy! If you have a love for gadgets and automation, this is your coffee grinder - newbies to the world of coffee and espresso making will enjoy the no brainer way they have designed the interface to give you exactly what you need from your beans. I spent about five minutes with the manual for set-up and now, with the press of a button, we had the exact amount of ground beans with the exact grind that we want for our morning coffee.

Over the years I’ve owned at least 6 different grinders. My first two were blade grinders (hey they were cheap)! Since then several burr grinders including a small hand crank model. All were just OK. But my new Breville grinder is the best, hands down. It’s so fast, intuitive and easy to use. Turns out the best grinds ever! Best of all, there are no fine grinds flying all over the kitchen!!!

I'm amazed at how poorly made this is given the price and Breville's reputation. It sometimes bogs down and jams. And the receiving container on the bottom does not fit correctly under the machine. It has a plastic stopper on top of the lid to close entry point, and this piece gets in the way of sliding it into the machine. There is a small depression where it is supposed to sit to be out of the way, but it isn't deep enough. So you are left with either not being able to push the container all the way in, and lots of coffee missing the container and falling around the base, or having the plastic stopper stick out (whiich looks terrible).

I wanted a coffee grinder that could grind course enough for my coffee press a medium grind for my drip machine and be capable of fine espresso grind for when I get a machine. After doing some research and reading dozens of reviews I decided to give this grinder a try.
It's a nice grinder, very well made and produces a pretty consistent grind. For the price you cant go wrong.

reviews.reviewTitle: Super Durable and Configurable Coffee Grinder
reviews.reviewText: This is the grinder my work has and we grind coffee with it probably 10+ times a day and it has been going strong for well over a year, so I bought one for my home. The hopper attaches easily, and removes easily and feels sturdy. Some other grinders I have used feel cheap and make me nervous whenever I have to take the hopper off (feel like I might break them). The Breville has a wide range of grind settings, and you can store your favorites as presets. It's very easy to use as well.

reviews.reviewTitle: Can't say enough good things about design and quality
reviews.reviewText: Can't believe it took me this long to upgrade after my Pavoni burr grinder gave up. This is a quantum leap for nuanced grind adjustments, adjustable timing for the perfect amount, and a magnetic pop out easy-to-clean station. One frustration is that my 52mm portafilter is just enough off that the base won't hold it in place, it falls through so I have to hold it for the whole excruciating 20 seconds of grind time. Ha! Pair with a wooden handle tamper for a high end designer coffee station.

100% satisfaction. After little play with mechanical and digital settings I got really good blend that gives amazing espresso shots on Breville BES840XL!
Materials and assembly have really good quality. I'm using it for a couple of months and absolutely love it.

reviews.reviewTitle: We used to have a blade grinder and we thought it was fine, but we got soooo sick or using a ...
reviews.reviewText: This was a life changer for us. We used to have a blade grinder and we thought it was fine, but we got soooo sick or using a chopstick or something to get all the ground coffee out. We have a Breville Infuser for espresso and an Aeropress for daily coffee, and this has really made a big improvement to not only the coffee, but also the process of making the coffee. It's fun to use and experiment with to get just the right setting for your taste and equipment. Plus, it looks nice on the counter.

reviews.reviewTitle: Works but they shipped the wrong color.
reviews.reviewText: Works great but very disappointed that I ordered red and they sent black :( I would have sent it back but after I ordered it said they was out of red and it was a gift! I hope the insurance I bought works if we need it since the color doesn’t match.

reviews.reviewTitle: Very fine control over grind and time.
reviews.reviewText: We use with a Breville espresso maker and the portafilter fits right into a slot on this grinder. There's a button behind that the portafilter can press, making the whole operation one handed. Also the tray under the grinder comes out for easy cleaning, and is held in with a magnet. Slick.

reviews.reviewTitle: the beans get stuck in the teeth of the grinder!
reviews.reviewText: Grinds well but when we have put in beans that would serve more than six cups, the machine has 'ground' to a halt and stalled. We have had to turn the machine off, take off the cover and pour out the unground beans and then the grinder cleared when turning it on empty. Not something I want to have to continue to do as often as has occurred so far. I am going to ask for a new one and see what happens.
I ended up returning this grinder because it was not capable of grinding coarse enough for french press, which they say it is. Besides that, it is stylish, quick, and pretty quiet.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great grinder for your espresso machine
reviews.reviewText: Have been using this daily for over a year now and it works great. After some tinkering with grind size and timing for both single and double shots, this now gives me the perfect dose every time. What I like most is how you just push on the holder and it starts grinding saving an additional button to press.

We've been usually this grinder a numerous times a week for a few months and haven't had any issues. It's a process to clean it, but it's simple enough. If you're in the market for a coffee grinder the Breville won't disappoint you. It's built like a tank!

reviews.reviewTitle: I made the right choice on this one!
reviews.reviewText: A quality grinder is the key! Any espresso machine will make impressive coffe when the grind is consistent. Very happy with this grinder. Size is perfect for my countertop, fits my portafilter for direct grinding, easy to adjust and operate, feels very professional and looks impressive. Dialed in perfect espresso in a short amount of time. Once set you can keep cranking out perfect shots. Only improvement they could make is lengthening the amount of pause time on the grinder when you pause it to tap down the grinds. You have to be quick to restart and finnish the grinding or it will reset on you and then the amount or weight of your shot will be off.

reviews.reviewTitle: Perfect first burr grinder for home for consistent daily grind for that perfect brew
reviews.reviewText: Love this grinder. A huge step up from my bodum blade grinder I have been using for years until I started to pay attention to the inconsistent grinds. Definitely a great starter burr grinder for the home. Easy to use and consistent grinds evertime. I used it mainly for pour over and I get the most perfect brew. I'm a big fan of Breville and they think of everything for ease of use. My only issue is when using the bin with the cover, the grind almost consistently miss the hole leaving a few grams of grind on the cover. Not a big deal but not sure if it's because the vibration moves the bin around mis-aligning the hole. Anyways, not a big deal. Just sweep it into your dripper. Easy peasy. Hope for many years with this grinder!

reviews.reviewTitle: The lid for the ground coffee container should not be used
reviews.reviewText: I like the overall look but the functionality of the container that receives the ground coffee is lacking. The lid cannot be used when grinding or it makes a mess. I was going to buy this for all our kids for gifts but think I will find another brand.

A great grinder at a great price. My 18-year-old grinder gave up the ghost and I just knew I was going to be in for some sticker shock. I found this grinder and am very happy I did. It is much quieter than my last one. The programmable features are sweet, the same dose every time.

reviews.reviewTitle: I just love it. I no longer have to guess the ...
reviews.reviewText: I purchased this after my encore coffee grinder stopped working (it served me well for 4 years). Now this is a brand new ball game with controlled weight measure along with an electronic dial to control the grind size. I just love it. I no longer have to guess the amount of grind as the machine controls it on my behalf. Highly recommended.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great grinder - happy with it 1 year in
reviews.reviewText: Had it for almost a year now and it's been a great grinder. It can be a bit finicky getting it dialed in but once we got it dialed in we just don't touch it and it's good to go. But for the price it's got a ton of features - everything we need. The noise level seems about average for a grinder - maybe even on the quieter side - but we still installed it inside a cupboard so that it's even quieter when making early morning espresso. We're using it with the Breville Bambino and a non-pressurized portafilter. For the price, it seemed to be the best deal around when I was looked a year ago.

Give this to my husband for Christmas. This one operates much quieter than his old coffee grinder. It does not build up static that holds ground d coffee in the basket -- empties cleanly and completely. 12 grind settings gives lots of choices, depending on what he wants to brew. Overall, very pleased with this purchase.

I have had this one for a while now and I think it is a good purchase. It works and the coffee grounds are even and the coffee taste has improved... I know. I thought the idea that a good grinder could improve the taste was the silliest idea I had ever heard... but it is true...

reviews.reviewTitle: So far I like it more than I thought I would
reviews.reviewText: I was skeptical of this grinder as I don't like lots of electronics. I was looking at a higher end one but it's new to the market and getting mixed reviews. This grinder is solid with great reviews. I use it for pourover and Turkish coffee. Very tunable and remembers the settings.

I had an OLD cuisinart burr grinder that OCCASIONALLY got blocked by coffee grounds. My husband wanted to get me the latest and greatest, so he bought this as a gift. IT JAMS ALL THE TIME! And the motor smells like its burning. I dutifully empty the hopper, take it off, brush everything inside and poke around with a pointed tool and it grinds again for a few more times. I wish I had my old cuisinart.

reviews.reviewTitle: Efficient, consistent results from this grinder
reviews.reviewText: Provides consistent grind each time. Seems to leave a bit of coffee bits on the counter near it from the chute blowing coffee down into the portafilter, but not the mess I used to have with the burr grinders. Hopper keeps the beans fresh for the seven days that it takes me to get through them. And it has made an improvement in the taste of my lattes and cappuccinos by providing consist, repeatable dosages.

Awesome, full featured grinder. Bought it to replace a Capresso Infinity grinder which would constantly stop due to the hopper being misaligned. While that one still worked, this was worth the splurge. This one is much easier to take apart to clean and more fully-featured. I use it for espresso, pour-over (Chemex), french press, and cold brew - it can do it all.

I was a bit worried paying this much for a coffee grinder, but am I ever happy I did buy it!! I absolutely love this grinder. I can grind exact amount for my french press and espresso maker, you can fine tune the grind as well. Definitely worth buying. Oh, and it isn't messy or staticky...thumbs up

reviews.reviewTitle: ... am looking for a bur grinder to replace our super messy one
reviews.reviewText: I am looking for a bur grinder to replace our super messy one. This container doesn't create any sort of seal and grinders spit out the side. I guess it grinds okay but for the price i would have expected a glass container that creates a seal. I returned mine.

Worked fine first day. Second day the grinder was stopped by coffee beans. You can take it apart and take all the beans out, and then the grinder will turn again. Then you put coffee beans in and the grinder stops. Makes a high pitched whine but can't turn the burrs. Trouble shooting guide useless. I sent it back.

I bought this Breville grinder since my Breville espresso machine built in grinder went out on my motor gear (last about year). Now this grinder motor start slowly grind or not able to grind, I had use same bean same setting and regularly clean grinder according to owner manual, it only last one year or less. I should check out amazon review closely before purchase which I regret I didn't. I find multiple user experience this situation year before I do. Bad grinder is one issue and customer service is another. Strongly not recommend this grinder.

After about a week of use, I've found my perfect setting for my prefered coffee method, the Ratio 8. It's a chemex style system (not sold on Amazon) and needs a fairly coarse grind. There's some confusing feedback, so I'll try bring some clarity to the product. To find the perfect output, there are only two factors, quantity and coarseness.

Quantity is addressed by the duration which the grinder runs. You can adjust the time directly or press the "Smart" cups button. The cups button is a good guideline, but ultimately you will want to measure and find the correct duration. Blindly assuming the machine has produced 'x' number of tablespoons because it was set to 'x' will lead to frustration.

Coarseness is manipulated in two ways. There is a 60 setting adjustment knob that provides a good range from coarse to fine (1 is finest, 60 is coarsest). This setting is easily adjusted and should suffice for drip to espresso. I do not use the unit for espresso, so I cannot speak to that use case. Additionally, the upper burr can be adjusted to shift the range of the aforementioned 60 setting knob. There are 10 settings (1 is finest, 10 is coarsest) and the default is '6'. Ultimately, I adjusted the upper burr to '8' and the knob to '55' to find my perfect coarseness.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good grinder, too fine for French press.
reviews.reviewText:
This grinder is very nice to use. I can set it up and then get a perfect grind with the push of a button.

My biggest downside is that I had to go to the coarsest of coarse settings to grind for French press. Even then the grind is a bit fine for French press.

reviews.reviewTitle: Grinder is quiet and produces even grind size.
reviews.reviewText: I have to really like something or hate it to write a review. I originally purchased a baratza brand grinder and I was very disappointed bc I brew a variety of ways. I watched some you tube videos and this model kept popping up. I used it this morning for the first time and it is extremely quiet. It produces even grind size. Great price for this grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great for Medium and Fine Grinding but Not Coarse
reviews.reviewText: The automatic dosing works very well as does medium and fine grinding. However, even with the upper burr adjustment, the coffee is not coarse enough for traditional French Press. The lid on the hopper is airtight to keep the beans fresher longer. And the option to save customized settings is very useful.

reviews.reviewTitle: stopped working just out of warranty
reviews.reviewText: Mine worked well until one day it just stopped grinding. The only way i could get it to grind anything was on the coarsest setting, set at 12 cups, and i might get 3 cups worth of coffee. Took it apart as much as I could and there were no blockages. I attempted to call customer service. Was on hold for 30 minutes, then gave in and left my phone number for a call back, but never received a call. Went to email them my issue, but they do not leave a simple email address, there is a 50 line inquiry form you need to fill out.

reviews.reviewTitle: Works as expected. A daily staple.
reviews.reviewText: Use this every day with my coffee. Works perfectly every time. I think my roommate hates me for grinding beans at 8 in the morning every day, but nothing beats freshly ground coffee.

I'm replacing my previous generation Smart Grinder BCG800XL - This new model is slightly quieter, the hopper has a better seal. I love the pause function, as I like to have my grinds settle in the portafilter basket before I take it out. Also nice, the default settings are ideal for my BES840XL Infuser.
I've seen reviews comparing it to much more expensive units. Sure, others have larger burrs, or bigger motors, but at this price point, it's easily the best.

reviews.reviewTitle: This is a great coffee grinder
reviews.reviewText: This is a great coffee grinder. It’s more suited towards an espresso coffee drinker as the grind is I. The finer side. I happen to be a French press guy and it’s a little too fine even at the coarse setting. Quality is amazing as with most breville products.

reviews.reviewTitle: works really well, grinds like i need.
reviews.reviewText: so far, works really well. grinds down to very fine if i want it to. convenient, to say the least: electronic dial-in for grain size; nice porta-holder for hands off; easy clean. i recommend it very much as a low-priced burr grinder for espresso.

reviews.reviewTitle: Makes high pitch noise when screen is on
reviews.reviewText: Ordered this because of the reviews and features. Received one item and it made a high pitch noise while the screen was on. Amazon sent me a replacement that did the same thing. Returned both and bought a Baratza Virtuoso and I am happy with it.

It stopped working after trying to use for the 3rd time!
I made sure I cleaned everything from the inside but it's still the same.
The screen seems fine, but when I press start it won't grind!
It's been 4 days now and I tried everything from unplugging to applying everything in the troubleshoot paper.

Owned it for a year and a half before the motor burnt out. It worked great when it was working. It is hard to clean and you do have to clean it farely often. I bought an extended warranty which I would suggest anyone to do. Well worth it.
after buying two different ones that never came on after plugging them in, I bought this one. It works great. Breville is an outstanding brand.
Second Breville grinder we bought. First lasted over 10 years wilts daily use. Was still working but could not grind fine enough for espresso. This one seems just as dependable

reviews.reviewTitle: great for the coffee snob in you
reviews.reviewText: I dont often post 5 star reviews but this thig is amazing. WOrks great for my coffee in the morning. I like how i can adjust the grind size and how the hopper holds lots of coffee beans. Great for my pour over coffee

I really can’t compare to other grinders since all of mine in the past were hand grinders. All in all, it’s affordable and works great. It is easy to clean. It works well and I hope I can get at least 4 years of daily use out of it.

reviews.reviewText: My third Breville Smart Grinder but my first Smart Grinder 'Pro'. This grinder is the best of the bunch so far. What I like the best is the ability to accurately set the dose amount. Coffee is expensive so eliminating any waste is a good improvement. The grinding burrs have been updated and are now adjustable, a nice improvement to further achieve the perfect grind. For the price this is an excellent grinder but it does have a 'built-in' lifespan. What has determined the lifespan for every one of my smart grinders has been the impeller blade wearing out. I am talking about three plus years of use to wear out the impeller blade. When this happens your grinder will begin to clog up because the worn impeller blade cannot properly expel the grinds and simply compacts the grinds until the grinder completely clogs. If your grinder is not new, and begins clogging-up, it may not have anything to do with oily beans or anything like that. Your grinder clogging-up may very well be a worn out impeller blade. Still, I feel this grinder is a 5 star purchase.

If you change grind sizes there will be a surprising amount of the previous grind still clinging to the interior that gets pushed out with the new grind. This is utter disaster for espresso. If you change sizes significantly you will have to manually, and painstakingly, clean out remaining grinds by hand between grinds. This causes mayhem when using the provided catch bin used when grinding for French press or other coarse sizes. The entire inner surface is coated in grinds like reversed breading on a shrimp.

2- If you are attempting to dial-in a grind size for espresso, or any other application, this grinder is effectively useless if you want to ever change the grind size for another use. The main display shows grind step from 1-60 but within each step you can move the dial freely (no clicks for reference as it's a stepless setup) a rather large amount. Which means you either have to find the perfect grind size and NEVER touch the dial again or you have to live with the fact that you will likely never find that precise setting again.

3- Clumping. When grinding on the lower end of the scale for espresso this grinder causes twice the clumping of any other grinder I've used or seen. I've had clumps a full half centimetre in size, and larger, with most of an espresso grind clumped.

4- The time-based preset is an utter waste of time. (no pun intended) I never intended to use this before I bought the grinder but it's not actually possible to to get accurately consistent results based on grin time. You want to use weight. Get a scale, weigh your beans to determine the right amount, and utterly ignore the time function.

5- The main button is stop and start, with no option for a pulse. This is definitely a lesser failing than items 1-3 but still worth mentioning.

The grinder has a lot of smaller features I like- the removable floor of the grinding area that magnetically snaps back in that makes cleaning super easy. The ability to start/stop grinding by pushing the portafilter in as well as the very convenient portafilter holder. The bright, easy to read display and the overall aesthetic of the grinder. However these are all minor points of style and secondary function. When push comes to shove, the grinder does not deliver the precision, quality, or consistency of grinds that I require with renders the other features moot.

Given Breville's reputation, I am extremely disappointed.

I've had the grinder for one month and, so far, am extremely pleased with it. When researching prior to purchase, there were some reviews citing grounds 'spillage' around the machine and also 'static cling'. As of today I have ground two pounds of medium roast coffee (two varieties) and have the following remarks;
1. I have had no 'spillage' whatsoever. I am using the Grinds Container that ships with the unit; possibly the poor review referred to other types of containers.
2. I was into my second pound of coffee before 'cling' became noticeable. The solution was to wash and air dry the container and bean hopper, and just brush out the top and bottom grinder and grounds outlet.
3. Grind size is amazingly even. I have tried to find uneven bits in the grinds container, and failed (4 times). By comparison, before getting the Breville I was using a $90.00 grinder (won't mention the name) that did (I thought - what did I know?) a good job. Grounds went from powder to obvious bits. Static 'cling' was present from day one. Grinder had to be cleaned at least twice a week. Minor spillage required counter wipe down after each use.

I have also noticed some 'strange' side effects that may or may not be related to the Breville. BB (before Breville) i washed my coffee pot weekly - there was a noticeable coffee stain on the glass pot. AB - I washed the coffee pot today for the first time in a month, not because it (visually) needed washing, but because I received a large thermos today and it needed cleaning before use and since the water was running....

My only 'con' comment (and not enough to take away a star) is that for the first week or 10 days or so, after 30-35 seconds of grinding, there was a distinct odor of hot metal. I normally grind enough coffee for a full 12 cup pot (55 seconds at #41 grind, medium roast). I don't know if the odor came from the burr grinders or the gearing, or both, but I thought it was worrisome. I loved the ground product but decided to return the unit if the smell lasted to the third week - it didn't, and has not been noticed since then.

I grind coffee only for a drip coffee maker, so cannot report on the grinds for any other types of preparation. And, for what it's worth as a testimonial, I am drinking a lot more coffee than I did a month ago.

Stan

This is one heck of a grinder. First of all, it's very attractive looking. It honestly looks even nicer than it does in the photos (I think the photos make it look kind of like cheap plastic, but that's not at all how it feels).

The grind size is extremely consistent and it doesn't take terribly long to grind. (Grinding 42 grams of coffee at setting 52 takes about 28 seconds).

It's really easy to adjust grind size with the big knob on the right. You have to experiment a little with choosing the number of cups or shots you need, but it's all very customizable. For instance, say you making 4 cups of coffee in a French Press. If you're like me and you measure your beans first, then put them in the hopper and grind right before using, the 4 cup setting at a coarse grind size might not complete all the beans in the time it use right out of the box. No problem though -- you can use the knob on the front to adjust the time to grind for 4 cups. It adjusts in 0.2 second increments. The one thing I haven't tested is the consistency of the weight outputted once you dial in a time. (Because I just do the weighing first and don't store beans in the hopper).

I haven't tested this for espresso because I don't drink espresso, but everything I have seen online indicates it works very well for an espresso grind (for this price range, of course. This isn't a $1500 grinder or anything). It does come with two portafilter holders though, which is very cool.

The hopper seems to seal pretty darn well. As a bit of coffee obsessive person, if I wasn't trying new coffees all the time through a subscription service, I wouldn't hesitate to store a pound of beans in there and just grind what I need each morning. And honestly, the container for the ground beans seems airtight enough that I wouldn't sweat it too much leaving some extra grounds in there until the next morning.

The adjustable burrs are an awesome feature, but I haven't had to adjust them -- I've been happy with the factory range so far. (I almost exclusively brew using a Chemex and I'm happy with the grind for pour over use).

It's pretty easy to clean the machine of loose grounds, so that's not a big deal.

If you're looking at this machine, in all likelihood you're also considering the Baratza Virtuoso or Encore. I can't speak to how those machines function -- I haven't owned either. I can say that the knobs and LEDs and stainless steel of the Breville appealed to the nerd in me, and the grind produced by this machine is acceptable. Everything I've seen on the Baratza machines indicates they are absolutely excellent as well, but given that this machine and the Virtuoso are the same price, I opted for the style I like. I have not been disappointed.

EDIT: Since I wrote this review, I learned a couple of things. First, the espresso-level grind is very fine and very consistent. I tried it for a cold brew and it worked out great. Second, you can hold down the start button and it will grind until you let go. If you put in an amount of beans you have weighed, this feature will allow you to either get a good idea of how much time you'll need to grind to get the amount you want if you intend on filling the hopper with beans, or, if you only put in as much as you need to grind, not have to mess with the timer at all and instead just grind until you hear that it's empty (the burrs make a very different sound when no beans are being ground). Third, I haven't found the weight output based on time to be consistent enough for my needs. I'm pretty anal about ratio and I only want to grind exactly as much as I need each time. I don't think this is Breville's fault. They can't control for bean size, etc. For the anal people like me, it'll be best to not fill up the hopper and store your beans elsewhere, then just grind what you need.
