After unboxing and setting up this new, pricier model, I have two complaints. First, as another reviewer noted, the coarsest setting is not as coarse as I would like for French press. And, second - which I can't believe I don't see in others' reviews - the electronic sound of this machine is TERRIBLE. If the bassy whirr of a burr grinder is part of what brings satisfaction to your daily coffee ritual, I advise against choosing this model. At minimum, seek out a video review of it at Seattle Coffee website or somewhere, and listen. The thing sounds like a remote control car. I'm seriously miffed that no one else seems to have thought the sound of it worth pointing out. Maybe I will get used to this noise; let's hope so. It is the opposite of a deep and satisfying sound of beans being ground that I have grown to love.

reviews.reviewTitle: The grinder has excellent features, and for a while it worked really ...
reviews.reviewText: The grinder has excellent features, and for a while it worked really well. But like the experience of other reviewers, it died within two weeks. Suddenly, it started making a horrible sound of gears grinding against each other and it stopped grinding. I returned it. While Breville has loaded a mountain of electronic features into this grinder, the company would be better off cutting out those features and using that money to improve the build quality. More metal and less plastic parts. I have a Quamar grinder that weighs upward of 25 pounds while the Breville is as light as a feather. I don't think the company can make a quality grinder with all the electronics at the $200 price point they're selling it at. Spend the extra $150 and get a Rancilio Rocky--built like a tank and will last for a long time.

I do not notice a difference in bean flavor with this grinder compared to my $10 Krups grinder...certainly not worth $200!!! It is very loud and messy and I have grinds all over the counter and device every time I use it. Very high static. The grind is not right--for $200 it needs to grind 4 cups into the receptacle included at the default settings for 4 cups. I have to screw around, wasting coffee beans (expensive beans) trying to manually find a time setting that is right and that grinds the number of cups I want. I am not sure what the point of something this costly is other than stealing people's money when it is staticky, makes a huge mess, is loud, does not bring the beans down into the burrs, so it starts to burn out the motor, doesn't grind the number of cups it is set to grind, doesn't make a difference in flavor...for me, investing in a Breville was a colossal and expensive disappointment and a lesson to never, ever, buy their brand again. I also will never buy something this costly unless it has a 3-5 year warranty, minimum. For something this expensive, the warranty is one year, which is telling of their own lack of conviction in the quality of their product and their lack of care for customer satisfaction. All they care about is taking people's money and doing nothing to earn it. I would buy another brand if you are looking for a good grinder, and do not spend this kind of money on one. I gave it two stars because, other than the grinds it spews all over my counter, it is pretty.

I have a portion of my kitchen counter devoted to a coffee bar. My wife and I drink the brown elixir daily, and rather than go out to get overpriced, burnt-tasting java, we prefer to make it at home. It saves us money and we control the quality. Our various coffee makers, frother and now this grinder are a bit of investment, but we looked at the numbers and we're saving money in the long run, and it is more convenient.

My preference is to purchase beans that are as freshly roasted as possible and grind them right before making a pot. This allows for the best possible flavor and body in my cup-o-joe. While some coffee makers I've had in the past incorporate a grinding feature, they were a pain to maintain and didn't deliver quite the results I was looking for. I've owned a white Braun KSM2-WH Aromatic Coffee Grinder for about 15 years, and the plastic parts recently started to disintegrate though the motor is still strong. I checked the pricing and was shocked to see it is going for 5x what it used to cost. Anyway, after some soul-searching, my wife and I decided to invest in a burr grinder to have better control over the final product. Most base model electrics start around $30 and the price skyrockets from there. Visiting a local store in an area mall, we were able to get this model on sale.

The Breville Smart Coffee Burr Grinder Pro Stainless Steel Burr exudes quality. It comes handsomely packaged and would make an impressive and generous gift to a home barista you may know. With a 1lb. bean capacity hopper, 60 grind settings (60!?!), and both programmable and manual dose adjustments, there doesn't seem to be anything the Breville Smart Grinder Pro can't do. With a little poking around, I figured out how get it working. The quick start guide is also helpful, as is the extensive manual in English and French. This is a serious machine with lots of parts and options, so there is a slight learning curve. You can store beans in the sealed hopper between uses, but it isn't recommended and I wouldn't keep them in there for more and a couple of days. You can grind to the provided airtight container, a coffee filter, or used adapters to dispense into a portafilter for espresso.

While I thus far love the Smart Grinder Pro and am happy with my purchase, it isn't perfect. There are lots of parts and cleaning can be an involved affair. The power cord is very short, limiting versatility, though it does have an innovative ring on the plug so you don't stress the cord. The cord does not retract into the unit and there is no on-board storage for the adapters and cleaning tool. It does take a fair amount of counter space, but is actually more vertically compact than other units I was considering.

If you want to easily store your grinder away after each use, and don't require all the options the Breville unit offers, then a smaller, more affordable unit may make more sense. I was happy with my Braun, but am even happier now that I've *tasted* what the Smart Grinder Pro has to offer. I've used it a few times but suspect it will last give the quality of the materials. Part of the fun is finding the perfect grind for your coffee (start with the presets) and being able to switch between a french press or espresso grind at the push of a few buttons. I love how it's designed and the brushed stainless steel finish looks modern and tidy on the counter next to my Ninja.

~ Kort
Very good for the money...

reviews.reviewTitle: Makes GREAT fine espresso grind coffee but customer support
reviews.reviewText: Well I tried to give Breville time to reply but they seem to want me to send more than one email to support to get help. I will just send the item back and get a new one as this one clearly has an issue. I even sent them video but they want me to do that all over again. Makes GREAT fine espresso grind coffee but customer support, meh, not feelin' it. 3 stars for the grinder when it works, -2 stars for it having something wrong with it and for Breville trying to make me jump through hoops to get someone to answer an email.
Very strong and powerful grinder. We are very happy with our purchase. We use dark roast beans that can be oily and the preforms like it should.
GOOD BRAND, BUT THIS ARRIVED BROKE, then they changed for a new one. It worked fine for one year. Then is stopped grinding fine, it gets cloged. They dont sell parts.

I bought a BCG800 along with A BES900XL a few years ago. Espresso machine was great, the grinder not as good as a Capresso it replaced. Though Breville claimed my BCG800 didn't need the shim "repair" of earlier versions (and the parts were no longer available), it never ground fine enough for espresso until I found suitable shims and did the "mod" myself; it worked fantastically until I sold both machines this week. I upgraded to the BES920XL about six months ago (it's at least as good as the BES900XL), but I had to run out yesterday to upgrade to the BCG820 grinder... times 3!!

I bought the new Smart Grinder Pro from a major, high quality, Chicago-area appliance retailer. The grinder malfunctioned. I took it back the next day, swapped it at the store for another unit which also malfunctioned. I took home a third (with an assurance I could bring back again for a full refund, if necessary), same malfunction. What the F*** is going on Breville!? I plan to call Breville on Monday to see if they have a quick, obvious fix, or it's going back and I'll probably take the plunge for a Mazzer Mini.

Oh yeah, the problem? The grinder will work with a bit of slow down/laboring at fine espresso settings for at most a handful of shots worth of coffee, but then it will start clacking as the internal mechanism disengages the motor from the lower burr. The problem quickly gets worse so it requires a coarser and coarser setting, and changing the fine adjustment on the lower burr doesn't help. It's either a protective "clutch" mechanism or gears in the drive train are "jumping" as the grinder seems to load up. The same varieties of beans (and much worse) went through the older model at a perfect espresso grind setting without a hitch, I can't imagine these newer machines are so inferior. It should be essentially the same design. Six different types of beans were tried. All were fresh. None were dark, burned, oily, rancid, clog-prone beans.

I'm still hoping for a positive fix for this, it would be such a handy machine, but I can find no forum discussions that offer a solution, let alone address the issue. I'll try to add a new post if this has a positive resolution.

Be sure to run a good sample of beans at the full range of settings before you go home with one of these, and be sure you can return it for a refund if the problem starts a day or two into ownership. I wish I hadn't sold the previous model.
...As an update...I returned the third grinder to the retailer. All the sales people in the department were there to see another faulty grinder returned. One of them commented with a bit of shock at the realization that the rest of their stock was likely faulty, as well. I thought of having them work with Breville to have a new grinder from a different production run sent out, but I had grown weary of all the time/expense/travel I had incurred from the process thus far, so disappointed, I asked for a refund, took a deep breath, and bought a Mxxxxx Mini Elactronic. I really wanted to save the bucks and hoped the BCG820 would function like the BCG800 (seems like it's essentially the same mechanism), but no dice. So instead of risking the same kind of disappointment and wasted time pursuing other "higher quality" choices that I couldn't actually see in person (not a lot of retailers nationwide that stock this sort of equipment) I went with a tried - and - true choice in use at just about every quality, coffee/espresso shop.

reviews.reviewTitle: Dishonest customer service and faulty product
reviews.reviewText: Don’t buy, broke on the third grind. Tried to return, but Amazon says no-return. Looked all over their web listing and couldn’t find that bit of data easily. Amazon, shame on you...
Definately "big bang for your buck". Met my expectations and more.

THIS IS A WARNING! DO NOT BUY THIS GRINDER!

I had my smart grinder in use for less than a year. Then for no reason at all the dreaded stripped gear breakdown issue rose it's ugly head. What will happen is your coffee will be grinding normally but then all of a sudden the grinding will stop but the motor will continue spinning albeit faster with a whining free spinning sound. Mind you now,no obstruction like a pebble or extra hard coffee bean, NOTHING!. I took the machine apart and found the drive gear indeed stripped. I should also add that if you use this grinder for Espresso you can expect failure much sooner that if you grind for drip.

The motor has a steel worm gear shaft that couples with a nylon gear. Therein lies the problem. Under the slightest stress metal wins and nylon
looses.

First let me say that calling Breville customer service is a total waste of time. I began to search the web to discover that this gear stripping problem was far more widespread than I ever imagined. I also discovered that it's an easy fix but..... Breville does NOT sell the necessary replacement part(s). A further search for "Breville parts" did bring up the gear but each vendor that may have once if ever sold it had it labeled obsolete or discontinued.

BCG800XL130 Main Gear
Part Number: BCG800XL130
Breville
Availability: Discontinued

There is no fix for this problem once it happens and believe me it will, you can toss your investment in the trash.

I ultimately bit the bullet since I'm serious about my coffee and purchased a Baratza Forte grinder which I believe will keep on ticking long after I have met my maker.

I have nothing good to say about this company or its products. This coffee grinder is the second Breville product I had to return because it simply does not work as expected. Every coffee grinder is basically two things - the burrs and the motor. Everything else is bells and whistles. I bought this product because it has some bells and whistles that my other burr grinder does not - namely the attachment for espresso portafilter that allows bypassing using the container. That particular feature as well as other "smart" bells and whistles worked on the item I received. What did not work was the actual coffee grinding. The 'espresso' settings made the motor turn but no coffee coming out. Coarser settings produced some output but very slow - it took me about 1 minute to fill a portafilter basket, a task that takes about 10 seconds using my old burr grinder. A closer examination revealed that coffee grounds jam the burrs.

Calling Breville support was a rather negative experience. Pressing 8 to be called back simply resulted in disconnected call - so they cannot get even that right. After fifth call and being put on hold I was able to talk to a human being who told me that the experience I described was "unusual" and advised returning the product to the vendor - which I promptly did.

Out of sheer curiosity, I searched this issue on the internet and discovered that it was not that unusual after all. Many people reported having similar problems with this machine. Some blamed the coffee, which is ridiculous especially that my old grinder has no problems with any coffee, while others pointed to a defective design of the impeller - a small plastic part that pushes the grounds to the receptacle. This looked like a possible problem with my machine.

Clearly, I got a lemon and that can happen to anyone. However, given the fact that this happened to me twice with Breville products, this suggests that quality control at Breville is wanting. Add to it a malfunctioning customer support line and prices twice as high as those of competing product - and you have a good reason to choosing competing products.

After hours and hours on youtube and reading reviews on every grinder from $100-$500 I narrowed it down to 3 choices and ultimately I chose the Breville Smart Grinder Pro and I'm so glad I did. The reviews got me nervous because there are complaints about the quality of the extreme course to extreme fines, but for what I'm using it for it does a great job. My wife and I got a capresso 505.01 cool grind coffee/spice grinder 3+ years ago for a wedding gift and it worked well, but the grind quality was a mix from course to fine every time we used it. So in the quest for a better cup we bought the Breville Smart Grinder and wow the results are great. We use this at home, for mainly Press (setting 60) Chemex (setting 49) and our delonghi espresso machine (setting 21). Those are just the settings that work for me currently. I do want to upgrade my espresso machine next, and with as fine as this grinder goes I'm sure it will work just fine. This unit is not loud, my wife has to go to work early in the morning and we have a baby and this machine doesn't wake the whole house. It also takes just about 15 seconds for 25g of 49 course beans made...not bad. The machine looks very nice (went with silver), and has some extra little features that I really like. 1) The bean hopper locks so I can change to a different bean. It's very simple to twist and remove. Once the hopper is empty I have found that a few beans remain, so just put the empty hopper on, and run it for a few seconds to get all the remaining grounds (not many) out. 2) Has a great display and nice adjustment knobs and easy to view settings. 3) Nothing feels CHEAP about this machine, and when I went to a Bed Bath and Beyond to see what the machines were like it person my decision was complete. 4) The machine will automatically turn off after 5 minutes of being idle. You're looking to get things done, and not having to worry about switching the machine off is just a nice little feature. 5) It goes come with a nice little grounds container with lid. Now I've found to reduce the mess it's easier to just remove the lid to the grounds container vs putting the little opening on the top of the jar open...less spilled grounds. 6) If you do spill some grounds around the container the base is removable and you can pull it out, dust it off and insert again no problem. It is magnetic so you know when it's attached again. 7) It does come with portafilter holder options if you so choose...at this point I'm just using a funnel that came with my aero press to get the grounds from my grounds container to the p-filter, but do what works best for you. 8) Hopper capacity is great, and the lid seals very well. 9) This may seem silly but the cord has a place under the unit to be wrapped up, so if you only have a short distance to an outlet you won't have lots of excess cord all over. In summary if you're looking to take your home grind to the next level this is (in my humble opinion) a great choice. I ended up using a 20% off coupon so after tax was a little over $170 which compared to the the Baratza Encore, Bodum Bistro, and Rancilio Rocky, was a great value for the money. Cheers!
Could add more stars after more usage.

I ordered this unit using Prime Now but can't seem to find a way to link here. But I wanted to warn others about this unit and highly recommend you move on to a different unit in your shopping.

I am a coffee aficionado. My main method of brewing coffee is pour over with a Hario V60. I grind approximately 200 grams of very high quality dark beans every day for myself and family and my former grinder was a Baratza Virtuoso. I love it but I get tired of replacing the plastic components that wear out and break over time. Unfortunately it locked up bad and I cannot manage to get the upper burr removed and it appears to need a more significant repair where I need to ship it back to them. I've had the Baratza since 2013 and it gets used a lot and I looked at it like 5+ years of that much use is pretty good so maybe it's time to get something new. I was also in a pinch because nobody around me sells decent burr grinders and I needed coffee in the morning ;-). I found this unit on Prime Now with same day delivery (Amazon is cool) so I went for it. Huge mistake.

This unit from Breville became fully incapacitated on DAY 1, FIRST USE. I still don't know what happened. I simply weighed the beans for the amount of coffee I wanted, dropped them into the hopper and fired it up. It went along OK dropping ground coffee into the container they provide (though it's quite messy and missed the hole a lot) then it made a sound that nothing in this world should make and all bean grinding seemed to stop. I stopped the unit and started to dismantle. Now I'm thinking rock or something. Mind you in 2 years of ordering and grinding my coffee from my seller I've never once had a rock (I had a few when I used to order Peets Coffee but never with my current seller) but I just figured today was my luck day. Nope no rock, no nothing. Just gummed up grounds and a terribly messy effort to unload, and clean the thing. My grind size was drip (42) so it wasn't like I was trying for Turkish or something. I ended up grinding one cups worth a few hours later and it did just fine so I was hoping that the lockup was first day jitters.

Wake up today, same exact process and same exact results as the catastrophe on day 1. Now I'm upset. The unit will go back and I just ordered a replacement Baratza. Mind you it's going to cost me a lot more to get the Baratza but life is way too short to mess with this thing for another minute. I'm not paid by Baratza or anything to write this I'm just keenly aware of how good their product is now after trying a terrible product. I have a couple of things from Breville and they are really good but this grinder is just really bad. I ended up getting a commercial unit that's all metal (Baratza Forte BG) so hopefully I'll have fewer issues with the wear parts.

If you still put this in your cart and are all in, take a hard look at the second picture of the burr and get ready to spend some time everyday cleaning that out. Not for me . I should have read some of the more critical reviews before buying.

Just to put things into perspective for people this is a sub 200 dollar price tag grinder. I am a home roaster and roasting on a BC 3.5 gas roaster. I use this grinder for my personal use but for a while would even use it for customers who do not have their own grinders at home and for what you're spending I have to say mine had been a beast. I have ground well over 300 pounds of coffee through my first one which still works by the way, and a few days ago I decided to order another as a backup. I cannot speak of the other customers experience I can only speak about mine. If I do a really light roast on a particular coffee I can tell the machine is worked harder but that is about it. No I do not clean it every day or even every other day. If the machine died tomorrow I would still be more than satisfied because I know it is living on borrowed time at this point.

My GF thought I was crazy to spend $200 for a coffee grinder, we've now had our Breville coffee grinder for 7+ years now. We use it multiple times per day and it's always good, nothing else quite like it for control and consistency. We are very picky about our coffee, we order our favorite beans and grind one or two cups at a time as needed for maximum freshness. Once you find the control settings that deliver YOUR favorite grind this machine delivers that again and again, exactly the same every time, perfect.

My real test for value is whether I would buy something again if the one I have failed, in the case of this coffee grinder the answer is a resounding YES!

If by some chance you get a dud, just order a replacement, these are inherently strong and heavy duty machines. Ours has always been flawless in function. When we go on vacation we grind up a plastic bag of coffee and take it with us, just the right amount for the days we'll be gone.

I looked around in some stores for something like this coffee grinder but never found this feature set without more unneeded features for a higher price.

When I was a child my father had a Kitchen Aid coffee grinder that was sort of like this but it was not automatic, he had to stand there listening to the loud grinding noise and shut it off when the level in a measuring cup was met. This Breville is fully automatic, with just a little experimentation you'll find the setting that delivers your personal grind consistently time after time.

If I had to find a fault with the Breville it is the noise level, it is not a quiet machine but no burr grinder is, the Breville is quieter than my fathers old Kitchen Aid with less high frequency noise. You can quiet the Breville a lot by just throwing a kitchen towel over it, I've wrapped the machine tightly in a large bath towel to quiet it down so as not to awaken someone sleeping, that worked pretty well.

Thee is nothing quite like waking up and smelling fresh brewed coffee, thanks Breville and thanks Amazon for making it so easy to find for a great price.

Wishing everyone delicious coffee.

It works well....when it works. I used once and sometimes twice per day. There is a plastic piece connected to the burr grinder that fails after a year of use. They replaced the first one after two years of use. The replacement lasted maybe 1.5 years and now hearing clicking noises and stalls - it is about ready to fail again. I only used high quality beans on the medium coarse setting (not even the finer espresso setting). Pretty standard overall use. It shouldn't fail within 2 years for the price. Also, it is very loud. Will try a Baratza next.
Haven't had a chance to use mine yet. I bought it because I know of someone who has the grinder and loves it. The coffee was great.
Awful instructions.I cannot get it to work with the instructions.Please send me an authorization to return

reviews.reviewTitle: Great Quality And Value - Tons Of Features - Highly Recommended
reviews.reviewText:
Have been using a Bodum burr grinder for the last 5 yrs. Absolutely loved it, except it has a plasticized outside coating that attracts dust. Grinds coffee beautifully but always has to be wiped down and cleaned. Time for a change I thought. I was willing to spent up to $250, so I started my research.

Came down to 3. OXO, Kitchen Aid and this Breville. I won't go into what the others offer, and instead will tell you why I purchased the Breville.

OXO - Decent machine. Problem, the gap between the dispenser and grounds catcher is too big and finer grinds make a mess. Has a one button microprocessor operation. Also no glass catcher.

Kitchen Aid - Top contender. Would have bought this one, but wanted automatic operation. This unit's strength or weakness is its simplicity. Select the grind, flip switch, then turn off. No Automatic operation. Cannot remove bean hopper when full. Not slim or upright. Bean hopper is only 7oz. Not even half a pound. Has to be filled often. This one has a glass catcher (a plus).

Went with the Breville. Primary reasons. Slim and upright, Nice nickel finish. 1 lb bean hopper. Completely automatic with programmable memory (presets) so you can easily switch between different grinds with the touch of a button. There's more. Bean hopper can be removed when full of beans. Ease of cleaning. The Breville has an infinite amount of adjustments for fine > coarse grind. Does pulls, shots, cups... and can adjust the amount of coffee delivered by allowing fine adjustments to grind time which adds or removes the amount of coffee delivered in 1 gram increments. Talk about precise, this is it. Tight tolerance between dispenser and grind catcher, no mess here.

Then Breville just wipes the floor with the competition by including 2 porta filter holders that allows you to grind straight into your porta filter. Again, automatic one touch operation. If you have used a Breville espresso maker then you know what I'm referring to here. Push porta filter handle to start and it stops automatically, or you can press it in again to stop manually and tamp if needed. There is a removable magnetic grinds tray that facilitates cleaning, and also allows you grind into a basket if you wish. That about covers the features. The grinds.... they are precise. Even and consistent from start to finish. No rocky chunks or unevenness. Its catcher is plastic, not glass. Its large enough to accept ground coffee for 12 full cups at a time. Seals too if you have ground too much. Its a little loud during operation, but the value, ease of use and consistency it delivers makes this easy to overlook.

reviews.reviewTitle: Don’t buy it and here’s why!
reviews.reviewText: Second one I’ve had. The comments about the worn impellers are True! It is a versatile grinder but absolutely know you will need to replace it with only grinding for 4 espresso shots daily in under 2 years easily. Breville has discontinued even almost all of the other parts for their grinders, including the newer models 820 etc. if u only need an impeller then google shapeways they make an impeller that works on the 800.. My next grinder will be a baratza or higher end brand.

We upgraded from an entry level coffee grinder. I read a lot of reviews and watched a lot of videos on YouTube, even called some coffee vendors to speak with their sales team. I settled on the Smart Grinder Pro over Baratza (and others) for a few reasons.
1- This had all the grind settings I need. The dial is easy to adjust and you can open up the grinder and make manual "micro" adjustments if needed. I don't really fell that it's necessary given the range it has out of the box.
2- This model seemed easier to clean than the others
3- This model included a nice canister that can be removed. We grind a lot for regular brewing but also on a daily basis make espressos, so it's nice to remove the canister and put in the portafilter holder.
4- Really classy magnetic touches. The bottom grind catcher tray is easy to remove and the portafilter holder also clicks in place nicely.
5- Solid build quality. This is a hefty machine and it certainly feels good.
6- Probably my most favorite feature (that I didn't even consider when researching) is the shot selector/auto timer. You set how many seconds (or shots/cups) you want to grind and walk away. You can program this for your coffee of choice (we did for espresso) or just set it to high for drip and walk away until it's done.

Overall, I believe that this has features that hits above its price level. It performs well and has taken our coffee game up a notch or three.

reviews.reviewTitle: A very well-made and well-designed machine
reviews.reviewText: I agree. This is a great grinder for the price. This is the "go to" burr grinder for anyone who uses an Aeropress, as once you get the grind and dosage set like you want it, it's a matter of pushing one button. At that point the ground coffee makes a neat mound on its tray that can easily be removed and poured into the Aeropress via that device's funnel. My wife likes to make drip coffee, and the Breville likewise makes that easy, as the filter basket fits on the tray as well. Figure out the grind and dosage and forget about using a scoop any more. There is little to no mess with this grinder, and it is very easy to maintain. It also dispenses directly into a portafilter. I've had mine for over a year and it has given me nothing but pleasure.

Great design, solid build, and excellent espresso results! I had an old Gaggia burr grinder previously and would never get into the optimal pressure range making my espresso. The grind seemed to always be different and uneven. First espresso brew with this grinder and my indicator was smack dab in the middle of the perfect range. One of the very best features is the ability to set a specific amount for different numbers of espresso shots and then move the dial to create stronger or weaker amounts which basically equates to more coffee or less coffee grounds. I was able to perfectly dial in the exact amount needed for a double shot without any extra waste. This grinder is also WAY less noisy than my Gaggia burr grinder and far easier to get the container in and out of the unit. Highly recommended!

reviews.reviewTitle: Save your money. They break. Buy a cheaper one
reviews.reviewText: Bought one of these, was very excited to have it. Spent a LOT of money for a grinder on it because all the reviews said it was the best. And it was the best and great and made me happy until about a year later. One of the plastic gears on the inside completely wore out. Completely stopped grinding. Tried to cotact the company which was virtually impossible. When I did reach an actual human being I was told none there are NO replacement parts for anything in the grinder. And there was no warranty coverage that would cover that repair. At that point it became a $200 boat anchor. Went to Lowe's, bought a $50 Cuisinart and I've had that for 2 years without a hiccup. Save your money, buy a cheaper one. You can replace 3 of those if they break with the $200 that this one costs. Looks great on the outside, cheap plastic parts in the inside.

reviews.reviewTitle: ... received this as a wedding gift and if worked great for the first 13 months
reviews.reviewText:
We received this as a wedding gift and if worked great for the first 13 months, at times overheating with multiple rounds of flavored coffee, but with unflavored coffee perfect grounds and great tasting coffee. Unfortunately at approximately 14 months it started sounding as though it was stuck, motor making some noises but not grinding for 30 seconds then stopping. We have been following cleaning instructions weekly all along, and when we started having problems I followed all instructions on website and even used a vacuum to try and clear possible grounds. No luck.
As out of the warranty period we have been trying to see if we can fix it and have found no instructions on assembly, and on taking apart have found parts are welded together making it difficult to try and trouble shoot when breaks right after warranty expires.
I would not recommend this to anyone I know, as $200 for just over a year of coffee grounds is not worth it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Breville products - not good response from company for problems w/ their products!
reviews.reviewText: I purchased Breville coffee grinder, modelBCG450XL quite a few years ago. It worked for just a few months and then the on/off switch broke off and didn't work. I called Breville and tried to trouble shoot...with no luck. I have purchased several other Breville products that just don't meet the expectations with the amount of money that I paid for it. The Breville mixer was just as faulty (leaked) and again I couldn't use it anymore. The only good Breville product that has been fantastic is the large 4 slot toaster.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not worth the money, sent it back and am happier with a machine that’s $100 cheaper
reviews.reviewText: A coffee grinder that would not grind coffee beans!!! That’s what we ended up with after only two days of use the beans would get clogged in the burr and it would have to be taken apart and cleaned only to grind for a little while longer and do it all over again. Loved the features and the style, plus ease of use (when it worked) but not worth it, ended up getting the Oxo grinder for $100 less and it’s been perfect, not as “fancy” and takes a bit more learning curve but still gets a perfect grind.

Grinder stopped working after two weekends of use. I primarily use coarse grind as I do a lot of French Press and on the second weekend of use noticed it did not grind as much as previous days. Upon further tries it almost stopped grinding altogether, under any settings. Followed cleaning procedures, after which it grinded fine one time, before failing again.

The issue seems to be with the grind mechanism and it's rather unacceptable for a product in this price range to not work out of the box as expected. Cheaper burr grinders don't have all the electronics but at least they don't fail after 5 times of use.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not enough variability, grinds too fine.
reviews.reviewText: I primarily brew with a Kalita Wave and a Chemex. Even with the grind settings at the coarsest (10 inside, 60 on main control), the grind is way too fine. Everything comes out over extracted. It’s a quick and fairly quiet machine that produces really consistent grounds. I just wish it would grind coarse enough to make it useable for those using manual brew methods.

Brevelle is replacing the whole grinder, but I am confident new will fail in about same time. Those grinders have lots of plastic gears and parts that Breville will not even sell for DIY repair! You have to pay foe service! I will not be buying this brand grinder any more after second one will wear out! Its pretty much guarantee that grinder will not live much past 1 year warranty. SAD!

I love this grinder. It is so easy to use, and I am able to change the grind size by the easy turn of the dial. There have been some complaints of the short cord, and I was frustrated with this at first. But then I turned the machine over and unwound the cord. So simple!

reviews.reviewTitle: Grinds OK; manual poor; customer support worse
reviews.reviewText:
It does a decent job of grinding but whoever designed the "extras" and the manual was deficient.

If you are buying this because you think it will store many programs, you will be disappointed. It stores exactly four user programs -- one for each grind group -- that it applies to all cups/shots in that group regardless of actual grind number within the group. The user manual is completely wrong on this feature.

Similarly unhelpful is the design of the 50-54mm portafilter holders. You are supposed to be able to work an on|off switch by pushing your portafilter handle in, but this only works if you have a Breville-type portafilter with three lugs, not the more common type with two lugs. Again, the manual says nothing and does not even show that they are using a three-lug item. Also incorrect in the manual is the specification that paper filters require a coarser grind than gold-tone; even Breville in other publications states the reverse.

IMHO, you should buy this -- or the simpler models -- if you want a grinder that grinds well and consistently. The bells and whistles of the "Pro" are poorly conceived and misdescribed. This company should hire an engineer to replace its Madison Avenue fiction writer.

I can't recommend this grinder to anyone. 1 unit never worked (DOA), the second unit lasted a week and suddenly the engine lost power and started running at like 100 rpm, which means it gets stuck with a single coffee bean. So I'm on my second return, but this time I'm asking for a refund, I'm not even interested in trying a third.

I purchased my Smart Grinder (note: this is a review of the BCG800XL version, but I'm posting this on the Smart Grinder Pro as well, because it pertains to their customer service and product longevity) in 2011, and it worked flawlessly for the first 2 years. Since then, the display screen has had issues, where the grind select cursor flickers. It continued to grind effectively, so I was not worried. This past year, it has flickered continuously when on, and it now randomly changes the selected amount when grinding, so it stops grinding early. I take meticulous care of the grinder, including regular cleaning. For a $200 product, I feel that Breville should stand behind this type of kitchen appliance, as KitchenAid, Vitamix, BlendTec, and Cuisinart all stand behind their products. When I called the customer service number, I was told I could either pay $89 for repair or get a new grinder at a discount. The representative was snide and dismissed my issue as "I've never heard of this, so it is your fault." I emailed Breville, so we'll see how they respond and I'll change my rating accordingly. I am seriously disappointed in Breville, as they market their products to be premium appliances of top-notch quality.
