reviews.reviewTitle: You are missing out if you don't buy something in this quality range
reviews.reviewText:
I have to say that laying down over 2 bills for a coffee grinder was a bit unnerving. Still, after buying grinder after grinder in the $40-$90 range for years you, at some point, realize you are just wasting money. I had also suspected the variations in the coffee taste (drip and espresso) were more to do with grinder inconsistency then my process. I can say it is good to be right!

Before I purchased this grinder, I did the normal reading of Amazon reviews and found the same thing you are finding: love/hate reviews for everything. Being unsatisfied, I branched out to other Internet sources and learned about the types of grinders, and more importantly, how the cheaper grinders are in my opinion misrepresenting themselves as being burr grinders. This thing is a real burr grinder, which as it turns out produces a VERY consistent grind and does not cause you to cringe while it is running.

The things I like the most thus far:
Coffee taste great, and it always taste the same.
I grind straight into the strainer or espresso filter, even at 5:30am, so I always have fresh grinds.
It dispenses in a downward fashion, instead of out the front at a 90 degree, so it shows no signs of clogging.
Changing grind size and time is extremely easy - digital display so you are not fighting an analog setting that moves when you bump it.
The occasionally small excess grinds that fall to the bottom of the grinder base are quickly dispatched by removing the base insert (simple magnet holds it in place so it is a one-handed effortless maneuver).

Short if is dying and early death, I think coming up with a dislike is going to be difficult. Very happy with the purchase; sorry I wasted so much money on inferior products.

UPDATE AFTER 4 MONTHS OF USE: I love it! Just prior to boxing this and returning it Amazon I decided to give it one last chance. Many purchasers on here said the grounds jar/receptacle can partially block the grounds chute in many positions. For instance if you push the jar all the way back, which feels natural, it partially blocks the chute. This chute is extremely sensitive to being blocked. So people suggested a different receptacle, removing the lid, trying to position it better, etc. I simply removed the lid. This worked wonders! 4 months in and I have not had it bind once.

As you will see in my review below, I thought I had already tried this. Clearly I had not. I still think this product could benefit from improvement. It seems to bind a bit readily. The jar is all too easily misaligned with the chute thus causing it to bind. But if you remove the lid from the jar, you should encounter no problems from it.

ORIGINAL 1 STAR REVIEW: Like so many others, mine is making loud clicking noises and refusing to grind coffee. I am now on my fourth morning with it, and have already spent a couple hours repeatedly tearing it apart and recleaning it to get it working again. Sometimes it will work for 30 seconds, sometimes only 3 seconds until it jams. When it jams it must be thoroughly cleaned.

I tried a million different things to get it to work.The coarsest grind settings, different receptacle that would remove back pressure, etc. I even tried buying brand new beans, just in case my week old ones were the cause (even though they're not oily, nor damp, nor do the appear to contain tiny rocks). I gave this thing every chance I could think of, no luck.

I don't think it's fair to call this poorly engineered. There are so many visible things about this grinder that are really well designed, from the hopper bottom that closes when you lift it out for cleaning, to the magnetic grounds catcher at the bottom. They put a tremendous amount of thought into a lot of details, which makes cleaning this a breeze. But, there are clearly a lot of defective units out there. Or, perhaps the all important internals weren't done by the same engineer.

I called Breville to see if they knew of any thing I could try before I returned it. The automated phone system offered to call me back instead of putting me on hold, it claimed I would not lose my place in the queue. "Cool!" I thought, "I love these." Over 3 hours later my phone rings, and immediately hangs up. I Google the phone number, and the first result is a Better Business Burea profile for Breville. Their rating: D-

I usually would never rate something 1 star, especially something with such an impressive exterior design. But, it's an expensive coffee grinder that doesn't grind coffee, and based on what I have seen an exchange is unlikely to help.

TL;DR: this is a great value burr coffee grinder for those who want to make good quality drip coffee and espresso at home. If you use a bottomless filter basket (real espresso), then the Smart Grinder Pro will do the trick. If you're making espresso with a pressurized filter basket, the Smart Grinder (predecessor) will suffice.

If you're making French Press or Moka Pot coffee, look elsewhere.

Some questionable durability...see updates below.

****Original Review****
I'm so happy I waited this long to finally get an ELECTRIC burr grinder after years of manually grinding with the Hario Slim Mill Grinder. To think that I wasted all of those hours translated into days of my life to save a few bucks is baffling now that I've been using the new Breville Smart Grinder Pro for a couple of weeks now.

First, a short backstory:

-The first burr grinder I ever owned was the Capresso Infinity. My parents now use it in their kitchen, but I couldn't stand this grinder. Never could grind finely enough for espresso, was difficult to clean, had static build-up. Frankly, not much better than a blade grinder.

-I then bought my dad a Bodum Bistro. The thing was a piece of junk and broke after only a few uses. Was never able to return it because we lost the receipt.

-My next purchase was for myself. The Hario Hand Mill grinder. Very inexpensive, very effective ceramic burr grinders, portable, etc. But after about a week of using it you realize how impractical it is to spend 10 minutes grinding coffee every time you want it!

The reason I waited so long to invest in an electric burr grinder was mostly because of paradox of choice.

I considered the Rocky Rancillio because I heard it was unbeatable for home espresso. Still, at $300+ and a nice hefty size, I was reluctant to take the plunge.

I also flirted with getting a Baratza Encore or Breville Smart Grinder, but each was reported to have its own respective issues that only prolonged my indecision. In any case, I was ready to go for the Baratza Encore until I saw that Breville had released a new version of the Smart Grinder, the Smart Grinder Pro.

~~~~Differences Between Current and Previous Model~~~~

There were a few improvements to the new model that had me sold on giving it a try.

1) 60 default grind settings vs. 25 in the original. PLUS, an adjustable upper burr for an additional 10 grind settings.

2) "Smart" dosing timer that allows you to adjust the grind time down to 0.2 seconds. The old model allowed you to adjust the "strength" of your coffee. I guess it was designed to be idiot-proof, but I think if somebody is spending $200 on a grinder they know that more coffee + less water and vice versa is MOSTLY what determines a coffee's strength. In any case, the old way was a silly and arbitrary way of dosing. The new way makes more sense*

3) Start/Pause button instead of a Start/Cancel button. Now, I never used the old version so I don't know if this is just different wording or not, but with the Smart Grinder Pro you can pause the grind and grind timer to say, settle your ground coffee in a portafilter before continuing the grind.

*This feature isn't very accurate in my opinion. I've weighed my ground coffee after using the same dosing time and had inconsistent weights. If you're serious about your coffee, I'd stick with a gram scale for dosing. I will give it another try and report back here though.

~~~~Repeat Features~~~~

-Removable magnetic grounds tray. LOVE, LOVE, LOVE this feature. Which may seem ridiculous...but I owned the Capresso Infinity where ground coffee was constantly building up in the tray at the bottom. This made the grounds basket more and more difficult to put in place. With the Smart Grinder Pro, keeping the grounds tray tidy is so easy because of this feature.

-Lockable/removable 1 lb. bean hopper. This is a decent feature that allows you to remove the bean hopper and change out your beans without spilling them all over the place. This is really only useful to somebody who keeps their beans in the hopper at all times, which I don't. I should also note that not all of the coffee in the hopper will be removed from the grinder since some of it will still remain between the burrs.

If you're looking to get more serious with your coffee, you shouldn't really be storing beans in the hopper. But that's just like, my opinion, man.

-Grounds basket with "airtight" lid/seal. This is probably my least favorite part of this grinder. The grounds basket itself is fine, but the lid just gets in the way and isn't even close to airtight. I don't ever grind the coffee into the grounds basket with the lid on.

-Comes with two different size portafilter holders (magnetic) and brush for cleaning burrs.

~~~~My First Experience~~~~

Now, despite my love for this grinder the first day of using it was a nightmare.

I tried adjusting the upper burr on the first day of using it and then the grinder just stopped working. I called Breville, we did some troubleshooting over the phone, and the rep finally told me it was defective and would need to be sent back.

My heart sunk.

Fortunately, the return process was super easy (and free). They even sent the replacement before I sent my defective grinder back in (with a $150 hold on my credit card until they received the defective one).

My replacement has been working like a charm though. And with this great customer service experience, I'm not inclined to take away any points in my review here. Only time will tell if it holds up though.

~~~~Pros~~~~

-It's very quiet for a grinder
-It's fast
-It is essentially stepless, even though 60 steps are displayed on the LCD screen
-Does a brilliant job for my MyPressi twist (read: espresso)
-Great price for the versatility

~~~~Cons~~~~

-Bad plastic/chemical smell post-grind that has seemingly gone away after some use
-Doser isn't that accurate, despite the improvement in the way it's done
-Grounds basket lid is useless and just gets in the way

So there you have it. I will update this review as time passes. I highly recommend this grinder for the budding home coffee enthusiast!

****UPDATE #1 - July, 2015****
Well I have to say I'm pretty disappointed.

I am now on my third unit because of defects. This grinder works fantastically when it's working, but unfortunately it simply can't hang with the finer grind settings. The burrs lock up and the grinder stops grinding when I'm at a grind setting below 10 usually. Sometimes it works, but it's like flipping a coin because you really never know when it will lock up.

Additionally, I've come to realize that the coarsest settings really aren't that coarse. As others have mentioned, this grinder is best for medium grind settings (and fines when it works).

Breville has been great in terms of customer service, but there is really only so many returns I can deal with at a certain point. This will most likely be returned unless a solution presents itself quickly.

****UPDATE #2 - December, 2015****
I've bumped my review back up 1 star because my most recent unit is holding up pretty well.

Here are some tips that I think have helped prevent the grinder from locking up with espresso grinds:

1) Always adjust your grind setting with beans in the hopper while simultaneously running the grinder. Yes, you will waste some coffee, but this is pretty standard practice when using burr grinders.

2) Never run the grinder with an empty hopper. You don't want the burrs making contact with each other if you can avoid it.

3) Grind in short spurts for espresso. I only grind a few seconds at a time, pause, and then resume for a few more seconds. I find that this helps prevent the motor from disengaging or the burrs from locking up.

Couple of other points that I want to reiterate:

-This grinder is no good for French Press. Look elsewhere.
-I've found that the ground coffee feels pretty warm sometimes after grinding for espresso (I notice when I'm dosing). I don't have much of a baseline reference for how hot (if at all) the ground coffee should be fresh out of the grinder...but my guess is that there shouldn't be any noticeable heat. After all, heat is said to be one of ground coffee's biggest enemies.
-The plastic/chemical smell post grind is almost always there. This is certainly disconcerting.

Do Not Buy This Grinder --- or any other Breville Grinder

Breville uses a cheap plastic impeller that wears down. The impeller is what pushes the coffee out after it's been ground. If the impeller doesn't work, the coffee beans aren't able to flow down into the burr. Apparently this goes back several years. I bought mine in Dec, 2015. This issue has begun to pop-up on the BCG820, but it's been happening on other models as well, like the BCG400SIL, BCG600SIL, and BCG800XL. The BCG820 has a metal “armor” that just clads the impeller, but underneath it is just a plastic part similar to the other models. This metal piece doesn't really do anything other than make it "look" like it's metal when you simply glance at it from the top with the burrs on. The issue doesn't start happening until after it's out of warranty. Mine started happening about 6-7 months after the warranty period had ended. Breville doesn't sell the part on its website to be replaced.

Google "Hidden defect in Breville coffee grinders" for details on the issue. There's a guy that sells a 3d-printed impeller for the BCG800, which can be found by searching "BCG800XL Grinder Jamming due to Worn Impeller"

Update 5/1//2019
I've been through three of these machines since I bought the first one. Breville sent me the last two, refurbished versions of the first one that broke after 5 months. These two lasted slightly longer. The company finally offered me credit, but I have yet to hear from them after a week. They keep sending me junk, and I told them I don't want any more of their machines. I'll go back to using my 10-year-old Braun grinder that has yet to fail me.

Update 1/16/18:
Called Breville about the problem and since the warranty was a year, they sent me a new machine, no charge. Customer service was easy to work with. I hope this one lasts longer, but it was nice to know that Breville stood behind their product.

Bought in July 2017. Dead in December 2017. Wheel that kicks coffee into the chute has worn out, and now it clicks and won't grind. This is the ONLY part for this machine Breville doesn't sell. Can't find it anywhere. Too bad. I enjoyed using it. Back to my 30-year-old Krups grinder, 2 cups at a time. I know it won't fail me.

reviews.reviewTitle: Can't say enough good things about it.
reviews.reviewText:
I've had the unit for 3 months, and I really can't say enough good things about it. It's far FAR better than I had expected it to be for the price. For coffee obsessives, it may not be on the same level as a $2000 Mahlkonig, but I'd be willing to bet in a double-blind test, they'd have trouble discerning quality differences between the two.

The grind is consistent, and provides enough range to use in both my french press, and Aeropress without complaint. The (ingenious) magnetic pop-out tray makes the unit easy to clean. Little touches, like the hole in the wall plug, and the locking hopper mechanism show the ingenuity that went into its design.

Most importantly - it simply works. Every morning I wake up, press the button, and the without fail, the same dose is dispensed.

If long-term longevity is a concern, go ahead and pick up the 3rd-party extended warranty, which is what I did. For the price, you'll still be ahead of the game!

First grind was fantastic, second grind was . . . PRODUCT FAILED AND BECAME UNUSABLE. The grinding mechanism seized up on the 2nd day of use and I was unable to clear beans out to get it working again. Failure on 2nd grind . . . seriously? Don't know how hard it it to engineer a reliable burr grinder but Breville really needs to go back to the drawing board. I note that both this product and one of its chief competitors in the price range, the Baratza Virtuoso, both have what I consider a high rate of negative reviews. Many give these products 5 stars but a consistent 20% + give 3 stars or less. Takeaway: the 4+ star rating can be somewhat deceiving if you don't bother to read the reviews.

reviews.reviewTitle: SERIOUS QUALITY CONTROL ISSUES, grinders faulty and not grinding fine enough.
reviews.reviewText:
This grinder although sleek and techy in design might prove worhtless to you as an espresso grinder.

I bought mine and immediately found it wasn't grinding fine enough to run a normal 25 second espresso, at most I could get 15 seconds. After trying to adjust with the many knobs and dials it has I found forcing it to it's maximum just to barely scratch the 20 seconds surface.

I started reading all around the forums and found that many people had this issue and, in Australia, Breville replaced the machine immediately. However I am not in Australia and shipping it back would be more expensive than buying a new one.

Bottom line: if you are buying this grinder be aware that many users have find their machines not operating correctly, so there's a good chance you will have to try different copies until you get one that works properly.

BREVILLE HAS SERIOUS QUALITY CONTROL ISSUES.

At the time I purchased this grinder we were making drip coffee at home. The machine does a fine job though it seemed that on a fairly course setting it still grinds the coffee pretty fine texture.
Skip ahead a few months and I decided to buy a commercial grade espresso machine. This grinder is working perfectly! I love that you can fine tune the number of seconds per dose as well as the fact the it does a great job of producing a fine grind for espresso.
When I got the grinder I had tossed the unnecessary accessories in a drawer and came across the porta-filter holder about a week after I got the new espresso machine. It’s a dream! You can slide the porta-filter in (there are two sizes of holder) then press the button for an exact, mess free dose. It’s one of those little design features that delights!
This grinder is less expensive and smaller than the higher end pro grinders. Few kitchens are big enough for those. This one is smaller than a drip coffee maker and much smaller than my espresso machine.
I have only had this a few months but so far I couldn’t be more pleased.

I was mainly looking for an espresso grinder, since store ground espresso never quite worked in my espresso maker--either too fine or too coarse. The Breville does what I want, and the bonus is that I can also grind for drip coffee, without any adjustment of the burrs. The advantage of spending more is probably a slightly more consistent size of grind, and possibly durability...but read on!

I was a bit nervous after reading about worn impellers. After six months of daily use, I took the burrs and impeller out. There is a bit of discussion here and at the Shapeways site where someone has 3D printed a replacement impeller for the earlier 800 series. The initial take by the author was that the 820 series has a stainless steel impeller. No, said several owners of the 820, it's painted plastic. After analyzing, to the best of my ability (including a scratch test), I conclude that the impeller is a plastic base with a stainless steel cover riveted to it. I will evaluate after another 5 months or so, but it doesn't appear that there is any wear in the impeller, and grinding works as well as on day one. It's possible that Breville has made incremental improvements in the 820 since it was initially released. Based on what I've seen, I expect long life from this grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: I was really excited because my espresso was 10x better using this grinder as opposed to my $40
reviews.reviewText:
This grinder worked wonders the first couple of weeks I had it. I was really excited because my espresso was 10x better using this grinder as opposed to my $40.00 cuisineart grinder. It is definitely true about having a good grinder can mean better coffee. Anyways, my grinder died on me within less than one month of daily operation once a day in the mornings. I called Breville customer support and they were more than happy to send me troubleshooting information. Once we finished troubleshooting there was still issues so they replaced my product no hassle; however, when I received the replacement unit from Breville it died on me after the first run at grinding coffee. Furthermore, after I contacted support for the second time about a second brand new device they tried to go through the same spiel with me about troubleshooting and how my coffee grinds could be old and stale.

As a result, I gave them the benefit of the doubt and bought brand new beans that were just roasted 2 days prior to purchase. The grinder still could not grind the coffee. As a result, I called back and explained to them and the person on the phone still was saying that it wasn't the machine. I began to get frustrated because the person on the other line was talking to me as if I haven't bought a nice $600.00 espresso machine with a $300 grinder and that I didn't know what I was doing even after I have proved to her that their troubleshooting didn't provide any desirable results.

At this point I was fed up because she was not being helpful and at the fact that I have not had a good coffee since my grinder took a dump. So, I figured I was done fighting with Breville over this and I'm going to return this product. THIS PRODUCT IS FAULTY BECAUSE OF THE CLUTCH AND MOTOR SYSTEM THEY HAVE. For some reason it isn't strong enough to grind the coffee and strips the clutch and motor. And then, when you call Breville support they talk to you like it is your fault, so just keep this in mind when you purchase this product.

I'm thinking they put poor quality parts in their machine that causes it to go bad like this but i'm not sure.

So far this grinder has been absolutely amazing! It has drastically improved the quality of my homemade espresso shots, just as I hoped. If you have an espresso machine, you really need a decent grinder to make good shots and this one is fantastic. I like the airtight seal on the hopper and included container too. Be sure to play around with your settings to get it right though- I ended up using grind setting number 22 for only 9 seconds to get the right amount of grinds for my 2 shots.

reviews.reviewTitle: I've accepted the Gospel of St. Grinder!
reviews.reviewText:
For years, I have had coffee aficionado friends, my mother-in-law, and a bajillion online forum posts telling me that a good burr grinder was the key to quality espresso. All the money in the world on a prosumer machine wasn't going to amount to a hill of gourmet coffee beans as long as I was chopping them up with the $20 Krups blade grinder which I've been using for 15 years. But I just couldn't see how it could make that much of a difference. And certainly not at the prices that rivaled the espresso machines they were meant to feed!

But for that same 15 years I've had a prosumer espresso machine that I bought after going through several cheaper models (in our house, the espresso machine gets worked fairly hard). I've had it serviced and overhauled every few years. It's plumbed in on a dedicated, filtered water line, and it's plugged into a digital timer so it kicks on 30 mins. before the alarm goes off in the morning and is fully warmed up and ready to go every day. So a couple months ago, I took it for service and decided that rather than pop for a shiny new machine, maybe I'd try upgrading my grinder to see what difference that might make.

I did my due diligence and researched the options before settling on the Breville Smart Grinder. Yes, I was considering a new $2K espresso machine, but I wan't spending that kind of small fortune on a grinder! What sold me on the Breville were several features. The removable hopper (you can leave beans in it when you take it off), the adjustable grind size and dosing, and the magnetic switch triggered by putting the portafilter in place. It took me a week or so of fiddling with the timing and grind size to find the sweet spot for my machine, but once I got it dialed in I realized the advantage of the high-end grinder. For years, I could get a decent shot out of my blade grinder probably 7 or 8 out of 10 times (I had nearly perfected the art of counting a certain number of seconds). But now, I was pulling shots at just the right pressure (9 bars) with thick, rich 'crema' every single time. I had accepted the Gospel according to St. Grinder!

Okay, so why did I give this grinder 4 stars instead of 5? No machine is perfect and this one has a couple of VERY minor drawbacks. One cool feature is the mid-grind pause. To keep from making mess all over the counter, the grinder can be paused, allowing me to tamp down what's in the portafilter and then pick up the rest of the dose with the same precise timing. Cool! But if I take too long to restart it, the timer goes back to the default and starts a whole new cycle. I wish the time allowed for a pause we're just a few seconds longer (a relatively easy software tweak, I'd guess). The other downside is the hopper is just a little shy of being to hold a full pound of beans. Not a huge deal, but it's a slight inconvenience to buy a one pound bag and then have to store the last couple ounces in the fridge until there's room for them.

Having said that, I just started buying Lavazza brand beans on Amazon in a one kilo (2.2 lbs,) bag. So now, of course, I have to store what doesn't go in the hopper in the fridge anyway. And here's the interesting thing: when I changed beans, I had to totally recalibrate the grinder. You'd think coffee beans are a pretty uniform size and hardness so should grind the same. But the beans from my local gourmet grocer would have to have the dial set much finer and the timer longer to get a decent shot. It took me several tries before I got the grind size dialed down to a little coarser and shorter cycle with the Lavazza beans. The bonus is, the Lavazza beans are a less expensive than the ones from my local grocer.

A couple of months in, and I'm very happy with this grinder and would recommend it to any serious home barista.

Update 7/1/16: I recently found that this grinder can't handle harder beans/ lighter roasts very well. It sounds like it's dying. I was grinding a medium light roast so if you primarily drink lighter coffees you may want to look into a different grinder. I want to get into pourovers, and am currently considering a hand grinder. I will update how that goes.

Original Review:

To be fair, this should be more like 4.5 stars because I do really like it. Bought this a few months ago to go with my Breville Infuser and they look so nice together. It's pretty straight forward to operate this machine. The only reason why I didn't give this 5 stars is because it's not completely perfect for my use. It seems the beans that I'm using would like something between the 14 and 15 grind settings to get the optimal pressure. The 15 setting is too coarse, so the better setting is the 14. At a grind level of 14, I find some small coffee grinds end up in my espresso and start settling out as it sits. Not sure if this is due to a few stray pieces getting through the filter, or if it's because the grinder is creating some sprinkling of finer grinds. I just don't drink the coffee at the very bottom. For the most part I'm very satisfied with its performance.

reviews.reviewTitle: Large increase in quality of espresso
reviews.reviewText: After many years of being cheap, I finally broke down and spent the money on a good grinder. Was it worth the money? Time will tell, but after a month I have had ZERO problems with this grinder. No static issues, no motor issues, no setting issues. I have been nothing but impressed and have put about 3/4 of a pound of french roast through it so far. I use it for espresso with my Breville 800ESXL, grinding directly into the portafilter, and it has made a huge difference in the quality of my espresso. The digital settings remember your setting (grind time) for single and double separately so you can set it for each. Still set me off that an electric motor attached to a burr costs $200 but there is really NO comparison in the quality of grind to the cheaper burr grinders. My recommendation is if you can afford it then you won't regret it.

reviews.reviewTitle: The smart grinder sounds like a great unit and will perform ...
reviews.reviewText: I am a daily grinder and I grind for multiple pots throughout the given day. I purchased the unit November 9 2017 and had clogging problems right from the start. By February 2018 the grinder was not dispensing enough for even a single cup of coffee. I contacted the company and they took care of me sending me a new unit (refurbished). I opened the box mid March and now June 2018 the unit is once again clogging. The smart grinder sounds like a great unit and will perform nicely for a few months of daily use but will quickly break down. This is an expensive grinder for only a few months of use. I would not purchase another one.

A huge upgrade over prior grinder in making coffee at home ... definitely improved taste and allowed us to reduce the amount of beans used.

We use it for drip coffee (Melita #4 filters) and a big plus is that I can measure out the beans and grind directly into the paper filter. I do have to hold the paper filter to do so ... it would have been really nice if it was designed so that I could grind directly into the filter holder and paper filter or 'gold' mesh filter ... but I'm still happy ...

We've been using it daily for over 6 months now with no problems

My old burr grinder (also a Breville) was worn out and wouldn't grind fine enough for espresso. I couldn't find spare parts to fix it, so I bought the BCG820BSSXL. On grind setting 15, it makes a perfect grind for my espresso maker, with plenty of room to go finer as the burrs wear down. My only complaint is that neither of the provided portafilter cradles fits my Gaggia Espresso portafilter. But that's okay because it's easy just to hold the portafilter centered under grinder outlet, and fill it without losing any over the edge. It was easy to dial in the grind setting and duration to get my desired 25-sec double shot. Some reviewers say it is noisy, but it's quieter than my old one, so I'm happy. It's also easy to clean the upper burr, and the hopper lid has a nice seal that keeps the beans fresh.

reviews.reviewTitle: Easy to use, a bit noisy, one questionable reliability item
reviews.reviewText:
I personally love this grinder; been using it daily for about two months. It is very fast and consistent. Just an FYI though, I use it exclusively for drip coffee as I have a high end Mazzer for espresso, which takes forever to dial in, so adjusting between espresso and drip would be impossible. This grinder can supposedly do espresso, I've just never tried it for that.

It is very easy to clean, and because the adjustment occurs on the bottom side of the two grind plates, when you reinstall the top plate your fine/course setting is preserved. It is fairly noisy; you will not be carrying on a conversation while it whirs away, and if your place of installation is very close to a kid or guest bedroom, it may wake them up. The canister it comes with butts right up against the output of the grind mechanism funnel so you won't end up with grounds spraying everywhere like some competing models in this price range. The canister also has a rubber sealing top, so if you grind more than you need and want to save it for the next day, no real harm done.

Last but not least, reliability. If you read through the reviews, you'll realize that this grinder has a significant weak point in a metal-covered plastic gear that sits under the grind plate. Many reviews point to this gear as having worn out, and Breville not treating it as a replaceable part. I nearly didn't make this purchase over this fact because I find it fairly obnoxious they would not sell the part most likely to break, which not only inconveniences the purchaser, but results in an easily avoidable significant contribution to land fills. The competing models in the same price range just had too many feature concerns though, so in the end I went forward with it, however, only because Amazon had the option to bundle a $30 four year warranty on it, so if that stupid gear does fail, I know I can get a new unit easily. It won't save on the waste, and I wrote a nasty letter to Breville about that, but I just couldn't pull the trigger on a competing model with less features.

reviews.reviewTitle: Review for French Press & Cold Brewers only (coarser grinds)
reviews.reviewText:
This review applicable to French Press users only:
I'm sure this grinder is probably fantastic for espresso & drip coffee, but the description says, "Grind settings allows you to go from the finest Espresso to the coarsest French Press." NOT TRUE. We had to change the removable upper burr to the coarsest setting, 10, and the electronic dial to the coarsest setting, 60, and the coarsest we could get was medium grounds. The grounds were consistent and it's a good quality, but not coarse enough for standard French Press and most definitely not possible to achieve, "the coarsest French Press". Maybe, one could argue they are on the edge of the finest possible coarseness for French Press.... but who wants a grinder where you are forced to use the very coarsest extreme to only get the very finest extreme for French Press? Pushing my French Press's filter is a 20 second chore with grounds from this grinder's extreme coarsest setting.

I called Breville Customer service to try to find out if maybe my machine just needed an adjustment or was possibly defective. They have you leave your number to call you back, but they never did. That was more than a week ago, so thumbs down to their customer service.

I trouble shooted user error reasons for not being able to get coarser grounds. I tried using medium, light, and blended roasts. I would take out the upper removable burr and brush out all the grounds around the lower burr to make sure it wasn't clogged and just making the grounds extra fine because of a dark roast clogging it up.

I'm giving the grinder 4 stars still because all of the other bells & whistles and positive comments are true. But knocking it a star because it doesn't achieve the wide breadth of grounds like they advertised. You'd think coarse grounds would be easiest to achieve but sadly it's just not the case with this grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Gets the job done in many cases
reviews.reviewText:
I'd recommend for people who want to focus their budget on good beans for hand pour, brew, and ice coffees.
Not for espresso lovers or OCD-type coffee drinkers! You'll be looking to upgrade within 3-6 months so just skip this machine altogether.

-This is a good entry-level grinder.
-Retention isn't that bad, results are reasonably consistent. Easy to clean.
-Works better in the medium to course ranges (pour over, brew, French press)
-Fine grinds are somewhat clumpy and, depending on the bean, the grinder may struggle.
*Don't pair this grinder with a prosumer espresso machine ($1,000+) and expect desired results.
*Don't expect to make endless shots in a row. Not durable enough for training or practice.

reviews.reviewTitle: Absolutely terrific grinder. I use it to for espresso grind ...
reviews.reviewText: I have been using this routinely for about a year and a half. Absolutely terrific grinder. I use it to for espresso grind during the week and dial it over to french press on the weekend. Shifting the grinder is lot easier than my old Italian Saeco grinder - use just rotate the dial on the side. The grinder display reads out both the numerical setting and the preferred brew type for it (press, drip, espresso). This grinder is also a lot neater than others I have used - no problems with a lot of fly-away grinds due to static electricity.. The grinder comes with both a cup for grinding large amounts and a couple of handle carriages for espresso handles. I have it sitting next to a Gaggia classic, and the Breville grinds consistent amounts day after day for one shot or two. This grinder is a bit more expensive than others, but if you routinely grind your beans, it's worth it.

reviews.reviewTitle: When it works.... It's great, but I am replacing it with something else
reviews.reviewText:
1.5 years in, and it's dead. For $200 I hoped for more. When it was working it was great. It was average volume, and had lots, but not quite enough adjustments. (for espresso)

When it broke, I tried to replace it with another Breville exact same model. The replacement brand new unit was broken on arrival. Major motor issues. I love my Breville espresso machine but am very glad i didn't get a "built-in" grinder.

I went with a Baratza Sette 30 at $50 more, with fewer adjustments. For espresso grinding I am not sure I will love the Baratza, with only 30 settings, but the Breville, doesn't seem reliable enough.

reviews.reviewTitle: A lot of bang for the buck. Surprisingly good.
reviews.reviewText: I bought this as a gift for my son, who is just starting as a "home barista." I helped him get set up with the Smart Grinder Pro paired with my old Gaggia Coffee Deluxe (modded with a PID and other upgrades). I was very impressed with the grinder. It offers plenty of range to spare at the finer settings to dial in and make small adjustments as the beans age. The grind appears very consistent in size and timed dosing comes out consistently each time. (Although I have not gone so far as to weigh each dose to see just how close to one another they are.) It has a lot of great features. The large hopper is designed well. I wish my Baratza Vario held the same volume and the hopper could be removed so easily with beans in place. The airtight gasket is a nice touch. I find the digital controls very easy to use. The portafilter holder and shield do a great job containing and funneling any flying grinds, and the nice, cupped, magnetically attached tray makes it easy to keep things clean. Should my own current grinder go down, I would definitely consider buying a Smart Grinder Pro for myself, at hundreds of dollars less than others with comparable features. I have no idea how long the grinder will hold up after daily use. However, I have only had excellent customer service/repair from Breville on other appliances by them I own, even when out of warranty. The unit is lighter in weight than I expected, especially when compared to the Vario. However, it does not skate around the countertop or feel like it will topple over, so I don't think its weight will be an issue for concern. It's a nice grinder that should work very well for most home espresso makers. Breville has really upped the ante on entry-level grinders for espresso. Bravo Breville.

reviews.reviewTitle: Best I've had, may be the best i its price range
reviews.reviewText:
I can only compare this to the Grinders I've owned. I started decades ago with a couple of blade grinders, moved up to a Krups $45 burr grinder and now this $200 Breville. This is the best by far and of course should be. As far as the performance, it only does one thing better than the krups and that is the fine grind. The Krups did fine, but not quite fine enough for the espresso I like to make. The krups lasted many many years and I still have it.

This Breville goes VERY fine, so fine that it won't go through my espresso machine. It is convenient in that I can put my porta-filter in and get just 2 shots worth, all adjustable of course.

The knock on it and the reason I didn't give it a 5 is that it's messy. I can't grind coffee without the grounds going all over the counter.

I'm also not sure if this is going to last 10 years like my last one and at $200 it better or I'd be giving it a 3.

Expected a lot more out of this for the steep price. The most coarse grind setting isn't close to what I would consider coarse, so it's not great for pour-over, the one method I use. At least it's a consistent grind. No powdery grounds in with the "coarse" ones like I experienced with a previous cheap grinder. The capture container is cheap flimsy plastic, would expect glass. The opening on the top of the grounds container is essentially useless because half the grounds end up on the lid or miss the bowl altogether with the lid on. Relatively quiet, pleasant grind sound. The default timing per "cup" isn't close to the correct grind time and is time consuming to correct. It's a nice looking grinder minus the cheap plastic parts and the main unit feels sturdy.

reviews.reviewTitle: I like the fact you can close the hopper and remove ...
reviews.reviewText:
This grinder definitely deserves the high ratings. It's relatively quiet and fast, definitely more quiet than my last burr grinder, and it has a very consistent grind. The fact it comes with a measurable storage container is just bonus. I like the fact you can close the hopper and remove the top to dump out your beans and put in other beans so nothing gets thrown away if you just want to switch them out.

The features this thing has are pretty good. The timed grind can make it a little difficult if you're used to weight, but you can get the timing down pretty easily and it's consistent enough. The screen is super bright, but it turns off completely when you're not using it which is great. The adjustments are small enough and go both coarse and fine enough to do everything I need. The price makes it all the better. It's not too costly for what it does. I think there are some other features I haven't used on it but it's simple enough to just get what you need ground quickly every day with no difficulty.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good if you only brew one pot at a time.
reviews.reviewText: I have burned through two of these in the last year. Something in the motor just goes, and it stops pushing out the ground coffee. There were times where I would brew a few pots in a row. I figured I was overheating it, so, on the second one, I started waiting at least 1 minute between 2 oz. batches of coffee. This didn't help. The first one lasted just over 1 year, and the second one about 3 months. At $200 each, I'm done with them. It's an awesome grinder that is fully adjustable, feels solid and makes a consistent grind. It's just that it's only great when it works.

I've been using this grinder for more than a month now, and would recommend it to others. I had a earlier version of the Baratza Encore, which ground well, but I always had to shake or otherwise stir the beans in the hopper to get them to feed correctly. Furthermore, the simple analog timer was not very useful, so I would grid a bunch of beans, then store the grounds, which defeats the purpose of having a grinder, and I still had to measure the disred quantity. After a while, I just stopped using the Baratza, and just had beans ground at store.

The Breville works much better for me. The beans seldom get "stuck" in the hopper, and the digital automation means I just a button or two to get the desired quantity and grid texture I want. The hopper top has a nice rubber fitting, which does a good job of minimizing air getting to the beans (but it is still open at the bottom), The outside is metal, not plastic, and the unit comes with holders and a bin for grounds. There is also a ton of custom settings, more than you will probably need. Currently, I'm only using the grinder for drip coffee, but it's such a pleasure to use I may have to purchase an espresso maker, as my old one died.

reviews.reviewTitle: I really like the features of this grinder
reviews.reviewText:
I really like the features of this grinder, especially the digital dose and grind adjustment. The removable bottom tray makes cleaning up a snap. The main problem? Just like many other reviews have stated, this machine is likely to crap out on you quickly! I got this machine in December of 2015 and used it about 5 times a week since then. Things started getting dicey in July when the machine started to make strange noise and then it would skip. Now it only skips and won't grind at all.

To be fair, maybe I should have cleaned it more. I ran white rice through it a few times, but that was it. I'm getting a replacement sent to me from Breville, but if the next machine breaks the same way I will ask for a refund, bite the bullet, and buy the Rocky.

Update: I spoke with Breville support and they were awesome. They walked me through how to fix the machine and how to keep it from jamming up. The reviews are correct in that Breville support is quick and very attentive.

This is the ultimate grinder. It took me a couple of time to figure out how I want my coffee ground. Once I got the grind right for my drip coffee maker then all I do is turn it on every morning and it grinds the right amount needed. There are no unground chunks and guessing how many beans you need, like with those little hand grinders. Whether you use a drip maker, cappuccino, or other, this grinder will do it just right.
I definitely recommend this grinder.

This is my second electric burr grinder. The first one died after one use. I use the coarse grind setting for cold brew. So large quantities at a time. It works great. I might try for hot brew once it gets cold. The only thing I could hope for is another setting for quantity that included ounces or grams. It is a bit messy. Coffee grounds fly all over the counter around the the grinder. I love that it is reliable and that I know it will work the next time I need it. I also like that the hopper holds alot of beans

reviews.reviewTitle: the grinder started making noises like something was jammed and did not grind any coffee
reviews.reviewText: After only one use at a setting of 19 using fresh Peet's coffee beans, the grinder started making noises like something was jammed and did not grind any coffee. I followed the instructions to clean it and removing all the coffee beans and grounded coffee to no avail. After my third cleaning try and spending 2 hours I gave up. I contacted Amazon and they refunded me.

Big improvement from the previous model, even though the changes are subtle. Grind and time are now a numbers, not a floating cursors, so it's much easier to set and fine tune. The time also counts down in tenths of a second, and it's really necessary! A final bonus, it is much quieter than the old model and doesn't wake up the house. Our old one was used at least twice a day, every day, and lasted about 18 months. I hope this one lasts longer, but it's already a major improvement.

reviews.reviewTitle: Very happy I upgraded to the Smart Grinder Pro
reviews.reviewText:
I wasn't sure about this grinder -- I mean I read the reviews and did the research and all, but my old Gaggia MDF has been heavy, built to last, and never gave me any trouble, so I was wary at first. This Breville grinder looked wimpy by comparison and I was wondering if I really needed an LCD screen and a bunch of knobs on a grinder.

I bought this soon after replacing my Gaggia Baby Class espresso machine with the Breville Infuser BES840XL Espresso Machine. The MDF grinder wasn't cutting it in terms of producing a fine enough grind for this new machine, so I took the leap. I'm glad I did. My espresso is so much better now and I've tried a number of different coffee roasts from medium to very dark and oily and the fine tuning that the Smart Grinder Pro allows really makes the difference. Excellent grinder!

reviews.reviewTitle: The previous cooffee grinder I owned does not work properly with the Breville espresso machine that I bought since the coffee grinder was not fine enough. That's tbe reason I bought this machine
reviews.reviewText: Does it job when cooffee ground doesn't clog. The previous cooffee grinder I owned does not work properly with the Breville espresso machine that I bought since the coffee grinder was not fine enough. That's tbe reason I bought this machine. In the past few months it did it's job. The crema it produced was so rich and very satisfying. However, after the grinder has clogged earlier this month, it constantly started clogging which I'm not yet sure if I grind my coffee beans too fine (which is also a problem, why they set the really fine level if the grinder can't even work with it), or my coffee bean isn't freah enough (if that's the case I probably need to buy coffee beans every month, so I probably can only buy the local coffee beans). I'll probably update my finding later just to be sure what's the real problem.

I love revile products, all made with such great quality, and all at a very good price point. This is fits that really well. I use it for espresso, which at grind size setting between the coarsest 15 and the finest 11, its just perfect. It has a bit of programability so it makes the guess work out of the equation. Grinds really quickly. Has a very large range of grind sizes, form drip coffee, right down to an extremely find espresso. Really just can't get any better for the price.

reviews.reviewTitle: A wonderful companion to our espresso machine
reviews.reviewText:
We use this grinder a lot every morning in our family. We have a Breville Barista Express machine that has a similar built-in grinder, but we got this so we can have two different coffee beans for the family (decaf for example in one).

No problems with it so far. The controls are easy to use on the front, but the side knob for the grind size is a pain. That requires a lot of difficult turning if you need to go back and forth between an espresso grind (fine) and a french press (very coarse). It is very cumbersome and nowhere near as easy as the other controls on the front. I'd prefer 4 or 5 presets for the grind size and then maybe a knob to fine tune it.

The bottom compartment is very easy to detach (magnetic) and easy to clean.

reviews.reviewTitle: Adjustments on the face of the machine are wonderful, easy to use and provide a wide variety ...
reviews.reviewText: Recently purchased about 3 months ago. Adjustments on the face of the machine are wonderful, easy to use and provide a wide variety of settings from very fine to very coarse. Also adjusted the burr grind one notch, but removing the coffee bin and the top burr for grind adjustment (or cleaning) is very easy. The grind is consistent and the grinder is a fair amount quieter than my old Solis. One caution, when you wash the bin when it first comes out of the box, make sure it is completely dry before using. I didn't let it dry completely and the residual moisture caused the coffee to clog in the burrs and I had to remove the bin and clean the burrs. Once that was done however, the machine worked fine and have had absolutely no problems since. Good machine-- recommended.

reviews.reviewTitle: It does a really nice job of it
reviews.reviewText:
I use this for Drip coffee. It does a really nice job of it. Being able to micro adjust the blades let me dial it in with the beans I use. We have 7 different types of coffee. 3 here in Ecuador are very popular. Loja, Galapagos' and beans from the Amazon jungle. When it arrived I dialed it in with around a pound of each coffee to find the best setting. After a couple of weeks it needed to be readjusted. Since then it's been wonderful.
I use a Moccamaster Coffee maker and a 24 k gold plated screen. Worker great.
I do take it apart each time to clean. I don't use the timer option. I weight the beans and just grind, then the beans stay fresh for each grind.
When it arrives, play with the settings till you get the best aroma and taste.
I would buy this again.

Bought this after hating two other grinders. This grinder works well for a wide variety of needs. We use it primarily for expresso. It can be configured to grind directly in to the doser. It also has a container if you are making drip, French press, etc. The attachments are simply mounted using a magnetic attachment. Works well and makes it simple to clean. Love it!

reviews.reviewTitle: my expensive Breville experience. Breaks every two years it seems
reviews.reviewText: We make 6-8 cups of expresso per day in our house. I hope this is adding to my other post....ONe of the several Breville grinders I bought was a gift, and I don't know how it's doing, but they seem to break on me, every two years. My son got a new part for his. there is a piece of plastic inside that appears to be ground away as the machine ages. So just know, you will get a grind not too bad, however, IF you are really into expresso, might reconsider brand of second one if you continue.

The impeller part wears out in about three years, when the product is out of warranty, and Breville won’t sell that spare part but requires you mail the whole until to them to be fixed for about a $100. I regret I bought this and wish I had researched its problems more thoroughly.

This device does an excellent job of grinding beans to the proper texture for a favorable cup of coffee. Once you decide the grind and time necessary to grind the beans, add a few seconds to run all the beans through the grinder. The pitch of the grind sound changes to indicate you are done. reviews.reviewTitle: I had the previous Smart Grinder which worked very well but difficult to dial ...
reviews.reviewText: I had the previous Smart Grinder which worked very well but difficult to dial in the grind for different bean. This updated Pro model is much better at giving a lot of adjustment for precise grind size and length of grind to 0.2 seconds. Every espresso dose is repeatable! The only negative is the old machine seemed to have a little better grind size uniformity. I grind almost exclusively for an espresso machine and the coffee particles from this grinder always includes extremely fine particles that pass through the portafilter holes.

reviews.reviewTitle: I did lots of research and I did not want to spend over 200 on a grinder and this worked out great so far
reviews.reviewText: My First Expensive grinder and it has improved my espresso. I did lots of research and I did not want to spend over 200 on a grinder and this worked out great so far. I have had it for 3 months now. When first using and you adjust the grinder to espresso make sure you turn the knob while the machine is adjusting. Also if you feel the adjustment isn't working turn it while it is running. Good grinder for great home espresso, really makes a difference.

First I want to let you know I am serious about my coffee/espresso. I make cold brew, french press, auto-drip, and lastly & most frequently Espresso beverages. Having said that my last grinder also a Breville, was starting to signs of wear through constant use. Since the last one served me well I decided to purchase another upgraded model. This turned out to be a GREAT DECISION. The grind consistency is amazing, making my espresso shots a thing of beauty. If this machine lasts as long as my previous one it will be a triple bonus.

I read the reviews here and other places, noting that several reported early failures. I thought the probability that it would occur to me was remote and I liked the feature set, so I bought it. This grinder is amazing!! We've had it for about a year now (I wait to do reviews until I know if we love the item or hate it).. Anyways, we've had it for about a year now & it works wonderfully!! We haven't had a single issue with it and it works exactly as it says!! Love it & thank you for turning my husband into a coffee snob lol.. You truly have never had coffee until you've had fresh ground coffee!!!

We love this grinder. We had been using a blade grinder for many years and finally broke down to purchase a nice burr grinder. The upgrade in the taste in our coffee is remarkable. reviews.reviewTitle: It works and it lasts (3+ years and counting)
reviews.reviewText: It does a great job of grinding coffee beans, which I mostly use for espresso/cappuccino. The important thing is to clean conical burrs regularly after every few sessions. I use the supplied steel brush as well as toothpicks to loosen ground coffee inside the grinder, and then shake loosened ground coffee is out. I will typically repeat this procedure 4 or 5 times until no more coffee comes out. The whole procedure takes only a few minutes, so it's no big deal, but keeping those burrs clean will assure their longevity.

Works perfectly with my Breville Infuser espresso machine. (As a coffee shop owner I wanted to have a good quality coffee bar at home without reproducing a commercial set up). I love that I can get precise dosing and grinding settings, I haven't had that tech before at home and as a result I've pulled shots that sometimes get dumped out and re-brewed. Now every shot is at optimal pressure on the machine gauge and crema is consistent! This only took a few attempts to dial it all in. I am so pleased!!

This coffee grinder is the best one I have ever used. Fully adjustable grind, easy to operate. Great machine for that coffee snob that likes to mess with the grind size for different coffee beans and roasts. Once you get the grind set then the time to grind can be adjusted for just the right amount of fresh ground coffee. mmmmmm

Before purchasing this I tried a few much more expensive grinders with many more settings. I could never get the grind right but I found this unit to be very easy to use out of the box and I can easily dial it in for drip coffee or espresso with no issues at all. Looks awesome next to our Breville Toaster Oven and Espresso machine.

reviews.reviewTitle: Do not buy this unless you want to replace it in a year.

reviews.reviewTitle: Does not grind coarse enough, no returns?
reviews.reviewText: No returns for an item shipped and sold by Amazon? The page did not mention that, the grind is not coarse enough for cold brew. Now I"m stuck with a useless machine.

I have a Mazzer Mini grinder for home use, and I purchased this one for use in my office. I read the manual cover to cover, and then tried to use the machine. It turned on, I used the recommended 12 setting to begin to dial in my espresso grind, and then I began to grind. The motor started. The blades seemed to whir. But nothing came out of the receiving port. Or at least very, very little did. Just a smidge of grinds came out. A fingertips worth, if even.

reviews.reviewTitle: This is a great grinder. I use it every day
reviews.reviewText: This is a great grinder. I use it every day. The grind and dose are easy to adjust and produces a very consistent grind day after day. This grinder “does it all”! I had previously purchased another brand and found out it did not grind French press or drip! I sent it back and ordered THIS grinder. I am SOOOOO impressed and the coffee tastes delicious!!! :-)

I had an earlier model Breville coffee grinder. It was a simpler machine, louder and not as consistent in grind production. reviews.reviewTitle: This thing is awesome so far

However, it's a grinder...I highly doubt any of them are quiet so not disappointed at all. I highly recommend

It's pricey but it's consistent, quiet, and high quality. I upgraded from a cheap Cuisinart and using this took some time to dial-in, but the consistent grind has been great. This also doesn't suffer from the static issue the Cuisinart grinder did, making it a much cleaner option to use.

I had an eye on this machine for many months and I finally bought one when Amazon pricing algorithm tried to match the rediculous low prices from the other sellers. I was tempted many times to buy the open box but I am glad that I didn't and bough new instead. I bought this on an impulse because my espresso machine, Breville BES870XL also has built in grinder, and I don't see it adds anything to my espresso. I also grind coffee with a blade grinder for pour over coffee. I have not done any blind test but I can tell you that people who claimed the burr grinders for better coffee is bullsh*t. Having said that, I got good deal so I don't regret at all.
I watched many video reviews and comparisons between this model and the others, and I can tell you this is the best for the price and performance ratio. You can't find any conical burr grinder out there that comes with many great features as this one:: 60 grind settings, nice LCD display, accurate timer for dose control, pause and resume, power saving, portafilter holders, removable bean hopper.. for less than $200. I have looked at these models in the same price range: DeLonghi America KG521 and Cuisinart CMB-20 which disappeared after released to market. You can step up to to Rancilio Rocky which is twice the price but I doubt it gives you much more for the money.
I have been using it for a month without any issue so far, and I don't need to cleap up the mess as I need when I pull up the cover of the Krups blade grinder.
I just set the duration and grind size that typically for the pour over brewing. We just need to put the paper cone filter underneath and press the button until the grinding finishes. The ground coffee is very uniform for coarse and fine setting as many reviewers reports.
So why did I give only 4 stars? It is 4.5 stars and I knocked off 1/2 for the maintenance requirement and this is not just for this grinder but for any burr grinder out there. Once for a while after finishing the beans in the hopper, I open up the grinder and brush off the super fine ground coffee that is stuck in there, or use paper clip if needed. I need to do more often if I use oily beans. My $20 Krups blade grinder is still running after 20 years without additional maintenance and I don't expect this one, 7-8 times more expensive to last that long. The idea of switching the hoppers for different beans is not that simple without grinding and flushing out the old coffee which is a wasteful to me.
The bottom line, if you want a little gadget in your kitchen or for your espresso machine then I strongly recommend this one. If you are looking for better brewed coffee then buy better beans, not the grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: I believe I've solved the problem of the clutch disengaging and causing the horrible noise - working fine now
reviews.reviewText:
This review speaks to one specific problem that other users have reported. It has to do with the torque-limiter/clutch disengaging, making a horrendous noise and leaving the smell of ozone in the air.

I had this problem and was constantly clearing the chute that transports ground coffee to the hopper. Last week it struck me what the problem was. My placement of the hopper was partly blocking the chute causing ground coffee to back up into the mechanism, become compacted, and prevent the machine from operating properly.

My SOLUTION, working fine for the past week: The hopper must be pushed all the way back in the front opening until it is snug up against the rear wall. This allows ground coffee to fall freely into the hopper without clogging the chute and causing the clutch to disengage. (when you glance at it, it may seem that the hopper opening is too far back. It's not.)

(It's working beautifully now. Four stars at this point for very small things like the timer returning to default setting when unplugged and difficulty removing the grinding mechanism for cleaning. Otherwise, I'm more than satisfied with the quality of the grind I'm getting.)

Finally took the plunge and purchased a burr grinder. This one does all I want in a coffee grinder. Grinds uniformly for my requirements ( drip maker), making a consistent cup of coffee. Burrs do require cleaning to keep them from jamming, but that may also be a function of the oily French roast coffee that I use. No problems after a couple months use. Recommend highly.

reviews.reviewTitle: Friends Don't Let Friends Buy This Grinder
reviews.reviewText:
Received it yesterday, demanding a refund today... Ground perfectly for about 5 seconds and then quit grinding. It just sat there happily and beautifully whirring away while producing absolutely nothing. Checked troubleshooting guide; followed all instructions; again, nothing... Massive disappointment.

Think it's a "one-off?" Think again, we should have learned our lesson from a Breville Blender we purchased a few years back. I owned this product for 25 days and then out of the blue the burrs seized and I returned it under Amazon's 30 day return policy (thank God).

Things I really liked about this grinder were:
- aesthetically, it's just really cool looking, in a retro way
- it does grind quickly, and the hopper holds a ridiculous amount of coffee
- the display and functionality are well beyond what most cheap burr grinders provide

Things I did not like:
- most importantly, this grinder produced a lot of coffee dust. This dust showed up as: grinds sitting at the bottom of the pot; sludge in the bottom of my coffee cups; and weirdly, a thick white-ish line at the top of my coffee as it filled my drip coffee maker. I thought all this was normal, since this was my first burr grinder. But I've since replaced it with another, and the new one doesn't have any of this
- kind of loud
- the dosing control is by time, not weight. It makes some kind of calculation based on your grind size (e.g. medium, or fine) and how many cups you want to make. But it's a very "ballpark" method. For instance, grinding for 12 cups on a medium grind (a typical full pot of drip coffee) you could get anywhere from 90 to 110 grams. Truth is, WEIGHT is what determines the appropriate amount of coffee, not grinding time. There is in fact a grinder at a similar cost (the Oxo) that doses by weight. Grinding by time makes no sense at all

- and of course, a huge, huge con is that after 25 days of working well, it just suddenly started making hideous metallic grinding noises. It was clearly broken and I was very thankful that I had purchased it on Amazon. In a half hour, it was boxed, shipped back, refunded, and a new grinder from another company was on the way.

I am giving it 3 stars, because when it's working it's a pretty good device. But it was certainly disappointing to see it fail after 25 days, that's for sure.

I've been using the same blade grinder for the past 15 years, and it finally gave out on me. Encouraged by a friend to step up my coffee game, I decided to upgrade from a simple and cheap machine to something a bit more sophisticated and expensive. I looked around at several models, and had a lot of difficulty choosing a burr grinder. For expensive machines, many seemed to have problems with durability. My friend recommended the Baratza, but I read enough reviews of people having problems with that brand, that I shied away from it. This led me to the Breville BCG820. It's a newer model than the 800, so I'm hoping that they fixed the issues that people seemed to have with the previous model. (Fingers crossed!)

One advantage to this model (compared to the older 800) is that you can simply dial all the way from espresso size to French press. The dial feels heavy since you are moving some gears up and down, but it feels solid. The grinds, in my amateur opinion, are fairly uniform, and there is definitely a difference in size when dialed in.

There are a few things I'm confused about though. When you grind, it grinds by time, and not weight. I would rather know that I'm grinding 30 grams of beans rather than grinding for 20 seconds. You would think on a machine at this price, it wouldn't be too difficult to put a small scale on the bottom.

At first I was weighing my beans, pouring them in the empty hopper, adding a few seconds to the automatically selected time, and stopping the grind manually when the beans are all gone. Now I've realized that the grinder remembers your time, so I leave it at 13 seconds for a coarse grind.

Another method it took me a few days to figure out was just simply holding the start button down until the beans grind, and letting go when I finished. This is only a secondary method, because who wants to hold a button for the entire grind?

If you do not care about specific weights though, the system easily lets you dial in for the amount of cups or shots that you are making, and you can increase the time of the grind to effectively increase the amount of coffee you want.

The hopper at the top holds 1 pound of beans. Although it's air tight at the top, still there is a lot of room for air in the container itself, so I do not leave my beans in there. Another reason I don't use the hopper is because I just want to grind a certain amount, and weigh my beans and just pour what I need into the grinder.

From beans to grind, there is a bit of mess at the bottom. If you use the provided container (with the lid), there will be hardly any chaff that sticks to your appliance, but the chaff will stick inside the container. I just blow in the container and it usually comes out. I have not used the provided collars for the two sizes of portafilter, but there is a slight mess, especially if you decide to grind directly into a container other than the big plastic one provided.

Size - For me, having limited counter space, going from a blade grinder to a dedicated machine was a big choice. It's relatively small for a kitchen appliance (about 6 inches across) so I would say it's not too bad, and well worth it to have good grinds, but it is another thing to have on your countertop.

Burrs - I decided to go with this brand because of the metal burrs. I'm mainly grinding for French press and moka pot, so I don't need the fine grinds that ceramic burrs can provide. Even if I decide to delve into the world of espresso, I've read that this machine does a decent job with fine grinds.

Overall - I'm glad that I've decided to invest in a better machine. I've noticed less silt in my French press, and the uniform grind makes brewing the coffee better because beans should brew for the optimum amount of time, and various sizes of grinds will make the coffee more bitter. Hopefully this machine lasts though. It's an expensive investment for coffee, and it can't be that difficult to make a grinder that lasts for a few years in this day and age, right? ***Fingers crossed*** please last Breville 820!

Recently I researched various burr grinders and settled on the Capresso Infinity Burr Grinder. I bought it from Amazon. Upon using it, I found that its most coarse setting was much too fine for French Press coffee. I returned it.

After further review, I decided to buy the Breville Smart Grinder Pro Stainless Steel Conical Burr Coffee Grinder. It was a bit pricey at $270 but I enjoy coffee and a grinder is something I would use every day.

I was quite disappointed to find that despite 50 grind settings, the Breville Smart Grinder Pro would not grind coarse coffee even at its most coarse setting. The machine is a beauty, with many fine features. But it is not suitable for making French Press coffee.

This week, I went to the store where I have been buying my coffee beans for years. They have a commercial-duty Bunn Coffee Mill for customers to use. I set the grinder to “French Press” and the grind was quite coarse, perfectly suited for making French Press coffee. I would love to be able to find a home model grinder that would grind coffee to this texture. I will be returning the Breville Smart Grinder Pro.

What a great coffee grinder! It has transformed my daily coffee routine. Now I have the perfect grind for either French Press or drip coffee (and now I want to get an espresso maker to try out the espresso-grind settings). A must-buy for folks who are very particular about their coffee rituals.

Perhaps I just happened to purchase a bag egg, I notice a lot of people getting amazing use of this great grinder. But for me it unfortunately did not meet my needs.

The Breville Smart Grinder has a wide range of grind qualities (very coarse to very fine) and allows the user to set the grind volume (the amount of coffee ground and dispensed). Very nice product. Works very well. It is loud when it grinds but otherwise a great product.

Kit butt burr grinder. Love being able to grind right into my expresso pods. Can't personally speak to the longevity as I have only had mind for ~2 weeks but my brother's has been going strong for ~3-4 years.
Best purchase yet! I'm a coffee addict! So far, the machine is running great! Many different settings for the perfect cup of joe!
This thing is excellent. Everything Breville is excellent so far
favorite grinder. love the flexibility and looks great on the counter. excellent for all types of coffee, from espresso to drip and french press. excellent product. highly recommend!
I thought I loved this product, until it broke after less than 1 year using it. How does a product this expensive completely stop working after only 8 months of use?
Very good grinder. Lots of settings and micro-adjustments at the burr. Gives you exactly the amount you need. Very satisfied. Typical high quality Breville appliance.

I purchased this grinder mostly to avoid the mess when using my current burr grinder. Now, instead of grinding every 5-7 days, I grind just prior to the brew.

The grind is much more consistent in that I have much less 'mud' in the bottom as when using my older burr grinder, AND while using a mesh filter.

Note: While I have tried the grinder at the most extreme levels of coarseness, I have not actually made an espresso yet. My wife, who loves her Lattes, is having health issues and therefore backed off her coffee for now.

On a personal note;
About 4 years ago, my Grandson has taken an interest in roasting coffee. He began using an old 'air' popcorn popper. Now, he imports the green (raw) beans, roasts and brews his coffee. He has opened two coffee shops, has a mobile wagon and has an online business as well.

Now that I am able to get Fresh Roasted beans, I wanted to have a Very Good grinder.
I am Loving the Breville and the VERY fresh coffee.
Excellent unit with all the bells and whistles. My only grip is the included plastic grind container has static issues causing the grinds to stick to the container.
Great. Only issue is the static electricity in the plastic bowl. For the price, a nice glass or pyrex container would have been better.

reviews.reviewText: Works great! Easy to use and adjust...would recommend it to anyone who wants fresh ground coffee! It is a bit expensive but you get what you pay for, it is quiet compared to other grinders I have had and the grind is uniform.

Grinds like a pro. This is a world better than a blade grinder as it creates a perfect consistency for whatever you need. We personally use the course grind for French Press, but when we finally get a decent espresso machine, we'll shift it to fine grind.

Full disclosure: I never actually used the unit. It appears to be (as I’ve come to expect from Breville) extremely well made. I toggle between making coffee just for me and for others as well on a daily basis, which makes that limitation a bit cumbersome for something so "smart."

I decided for my simple pour over needs, this appliance was going to be more complicated than I needed. Without putting a single bean in the hopper, I decided to return it. Guess what (and this is a first on Amazon for me)? It’s non-returnable. I can’t see where it says that on the Amazon order page, though the rep I spoke to on the phone told me it was on there.
