reviews.reviewTitle: After a few weeks they seem to work well and ...
reviews.reviewText: After a few weeks they seem to work well and appear to be made well enough to not readily fall apart.

We make espresso daily, and are now on the second Breville grinder. After about a couple of years of use, the first one started slowing down, struggling, and then failing in a matter of weeks. The same is now happening to the second one.

If you make espresso daily, do not waste your money on Breville grinders. Google "Breville grinder impeller" and you'll see that these grinders are built to wear out quickly, and while you could fix the old model, the new one you can't fix.

UPDATE: July, 2018
Having nothing left to lose, I took the grinder apart, and can attest that Breville has intentionally designed obsolescence into their coffee grinders. The impeller, which is the part that is responsible for expelling coffee grinds is made of plastic covered by metal - see picture.

In the picture of the impeller, you can see that plastic "teeth" used to expel coffee grinds are completely worn out (they), and the metal teeth are too short. Had the metal teeth been made a little longer, there would be no need for plastic, and this part would last forever. Clearly, Breville doesn't want it to last.

On the previous model of this grinder BCG800, it was possible to replace the worn out impeller by a 3rd party one. Clearly, Breville didn't like that either, since they went out of their way to redesign the impeller assembly in a way that makes it impossible to fix this yourself.

While it's understandable for any product to have flaws, it's a bit perplexing that a manufacturer would go out of their way to engineer the new model in a way that guarantees that the "flaw" can not be fixed by the customer.

Well done Breville - you've lost a loyal customer..

reviews.reviewTitle: Quality Grinder and Excellent Breville Service Department
reviews.reviewText: I received one of these as a Christmas gift a couple years ago. We use it daily and it performs an excellent, consistent grind that can be easily customized for a perfect coffee product. It has a convenient bean hopper and an adapter for the paper cone (or plastic cup) to catch the grind. The Breville customer service resolved a problem immediately with no push back and including a no cost, fast Fedex shipment. I will definitely shop the Breville product line in the future.

I am giving this product 3 stars without even using it because of the terrible customer support of Breville. Also because I have enough coffee grinds left for another pot (I am going from being a grind person to a bean person). I tried to contact Breville customer support to ask questions on how to use this machine, but their website has been down for days, and up now, but there is no way to contact them via e-mail as you keep getting routed to a dead end screen. I called their 866 number and was put on hold for 30' so I gave up. They do give you the option for a callback if you leave a number but I this is not amenable for me. So I have this brand new grinder but have not used it so far. I will update my rating later after I put the grinder in use.

Ok, this grinder has taken my home coffee and espresso game to a whole ‘nother level. You want French Press grind - perfect. You like Turkish - got it. Oh regular drip - meh...child’s play. This machine excels in the precision grind size it is capable of providing and the exact dose/weight/time for your next fix. I have become a Home based barista for my wife and kids. This machine looks impressive on my finely polished granite counter tops sitting between my drip coffee maker and my DeLonghi EC860 espresso/cappuccino machine (separate review). I chose the brushed stainless steel version to complete the look of my industrial chic coffee counter space.

Just grinding the beans in this elegant beast for either espresso or drip machine will give off a permeating smell to command all coffee junkies to begin asking questions and lining up in awe with their order.

Machine is a workhorse and is easily cleaned and maintained.

Now the bad news. This machine is noisy. I mean wake people up loud. I firmly believe that the Breville engineer or engineering team was deaf and had no idea how loud this machine was through the design and validation process. When I say loud I mean stop your conversation because this machine demands to be heard. I think it is a key design feature to draw attention and perpetuate its use because the fine quality and smells it put out will surely cause all around to want to use it more drink more coffee and likely buy this machine for their own daily use. As such, you can use it as a morning alarm clock with the 20 second double shot #18 espresso grind. Biggest challenge is trying to make my quad flat white quietly first before my wife asks for her double shot with coconut milk and two pumps of caramel...But I digress.

Great machine. 1 star deduction for noisiness - ear protection may be required for frequent use but I have grown to appreciate the noise these finely engineered Conical Burrs and 2hp motor make when preparing my morning fix. It somehow makes me feel powerful, like starting a chainsaw or launching a rocket into space. This machine has made me a better person by providing joy, albeit in small 6-8 ounce cups, to all who care to join me for my daily caffeine fix.

I just bought my third Breville Burr grinder. The first one lasted barely two years--I grind beans for one large cup of coffee each day, roughly 3 shots' worth. I complained to Breville and they agreed to send me a refurbished replacement. That machine died two weeks ago, after barely three years of the same one cup per day. After lots of research, I actually bought a third one. I have not opened it and am considering returning it. Can you only expect this much of a $200 coffee grinder? I performed all the cleaning and maintenance required. The machine is a great pleasure to use and performs wonderfully, but I am so tired of paying top dollar for things that barely last. Really not sure what to do!!! Pretty sure I am having the impeller issue discussed in other reviews.

Update, finally opened it. The motor sounds completely different than the last two, and really sounds much less powerful and as if it is struggling. My advice is to NOT buy this grinder.

Worked well for our daily morning pot-o-coffee, until about 9 months in, then stopped. Called Breville customer service who emailed a pre-paid return label for me to send the machine to them and they promptly shipped me out a new machine. This 2nd machine worked well for about 9 months and then stopped working. Super bummed, because when it was working, it worked great. Currently researching for a new grinder that lasts longer than 9 months at a time.

reviews.reviewTitle: Nice grinder but has limited lifespan
reviews.reviewText: The most helpful review from Merry K says if all. 3 years in and this thing is now going in the bin. Impeller teeth got worn down, ground coffee wasn’t coming out. End of story. And following their instructions on cleaning it by running rice through it. Thus, I threw it out. To summarize. It does not do a good job of grinding. It is expensive to purchase. reviews.reviewTitle: Hard to beat for the money--and yes--for espresso
reviews.reviewText:
I have a Quick Mill E61 espresso machine and use the Pro at setting 12 (11-14 depending on the bean) to deliver an excellent grind that gives me 48 ml of espresso with an 18g dose in ~35 secs overall. I mostly drink lattes, but take a couple of sips each time to get a taste of the extraction.

For espresso neat, I use 17 gm and ~35 ml in <30 sec. I use a bottomless PF and VST 18 g basket, and most of the time, I get no spritzers; and when I do, they are minor. At setting 11 and ~30 lb tamp force, I'll choke the machine, almost. At 12, it's just right, with some beans; others require 14 setting.

It's smoothly quiet. I weigh fresh-roasted (3 days - 2 weeks) beans on a small electronic scale from Amazon ($15). I put in 18.0 gm and get 17.8 gm every time, representing ~1% retention. If I tap the unit, I will get 100% recovery, every time. I grind single doses into a paper dixi cup which, upside down, fits into the 58 mm bottomless portafilter. I tap the mound so it is almost level with top of basket, and then tamp, and a light polish.

ZERO static--ZERO mess--almost zero retention, quiet, consistent, excellent grinding range, nice looking on the counter. Very little clumping, and the clumps break with a slight touch of the finger. For the money, my opinion is that this is a fantastic grinder and goes from pour-over 'clever' (~45 grind setting) to espresso (12 setting) and the grind is rock solid going from one to the other. It offers an excellent grind for espresso. This is not as easy as it sounds to achieve for ~$200.

The only other unit I might consider is a Baratza Vario--but--is it worth 2X the cost? Maybe. It seems much more solid; however, it get complaints also about failure to hold its setting (I think Baratza fixed this). I have read online that folks who had both give a slight nod to Vario for taste; but, how do you run a truly 'controlled' comparison? In a latte or capp, it's hard to believe anyone could tell. BTW, my taste buds are very sensitive to shot quality, even in a latte. The quality of the bean and freshness are important to me. Straight shots are sensitive to EVERY variable (grind, tamp, time, temp, bean type). This tells me the Pro is doing it's job correctly, yes?

For this price, the Smart Pro has no competition. So long as it lasts, I could not be more delighted.

**My first unit was a refurb, which was awful. I discovered its rate of 1 gm per 2 secs: too slow, and it jammed constantly. I bought a retail unit and it has functioned PERFECTLY and CONSISTENTLY for almost 6 months now. Breville was supportive--very, and took back the refurb at their expense and provided a fast refund.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not that hard to keep clean
reviews.reviewText: I received this as a Mother’s Day gift. I was using a manual coffee grinder and just wanted something quicker. When I read the reviews I was a little skeptical about keeping the grinder clean as so much was written about that. I have used this for a month cleaning is a snap. I clean it about every 3rd time. I just remove the parts throw them in the sink with a little soap and water then turn the grinder upside down over the sink and shake out anything that is loose. It literally takes me less than 3 minutes. So far it works great. I have made aeropress, french press, pour over and drip coffee they all have turned out great.

reviews.reviewTitle: Avoid if you live in dry climates
reviews.reviewText:
I've had good luck with a lot of Breville products and I want to like this thing because of the consistency and one touch operation but this thing just makes an insane mess all over the counter and I think it's a combination of a few things:

1. I live in Northern Nevada where it's usually extremely dry.
2. This thing doesn't make any kind of real seal between the grinder and the receptacle. It just kinda sits under the discharge chute.
Possible 3: Materials used in the grinder create more static than some other ones.

All of this means static electricity causes coffee grounds to go EVERYWHERE. After grinding you can see static making the grounds cling to the side of the receptacle. No matter how much care you take, they end up all over the place.

After dealing with the mess this thing makes for a year we finally replaced it with a different (cheaper) grinder with a better design and bingo, no more mess.

Had to replace it after over 8 years. The internal grears broke. Use it 4 to 9 times a day for double shot. A commercial unit is well over four time or more the cost. This unit is not as heavy duty as the commercial ones but for a small office or home it is very good. The key is to clean it once a month. So over its life it cost two large Starbuck coffee a year. The features are very good but you have to change setting when you change coffee or brewer. I use it with the larger Breville double broiler espresso cappuccino maker.

reviews.reviewTitle: Grinding like a champ. Smart and easy to use.
reviews.reviewText:
I bought a Rancillio Silva V4 and researched which grinder to get for it. There was much opinion that you really need a good grinder that can grind fine, evenly and consistently for the Rancillio. Several sites claim that you need specific brands to go with a Rancillio often between the $500 and $800 mark.

I researched this grinder carefully before I bought it. I watched videos comparing it against other brands and then I pulled the trigger and bought it. I’ve had it for a little over a month and it has been working like a champ. There is a massive range of grind sizes and it definitely can grind a variety of roasts very finely.

The machine seems to be quite well made and is smartly put together. You can take out the burrs to adjust, you can program grinds, grind in to portafilter or container, etc.

There are many more technical reviews that you can search out if you need. The bottom line for me is that it is a high quality grinder that is made well. So far it works better than expected and I see no reason why it should fail. Breville offer a 1 year warranty too.

I am very pleased with this machine and the price point. I grind Black Cat espresso (Intelligentsia) and Old School espresso (49th Parallel) as standards. I have tried a few darker roasts with out incident. I imagine more oily roasts would require increased maintenance and cleaning (which is easy on this machine).

Absolutely NO issue with getting a fine, power grind. In fact I have had to adjust it to a coarser grind to get the right tamp/extraction balance for my espresso.

(Thankfully) I can’t comment on replacement parts or repairs at this time as I haven’t had any problems.

Pros: Great price point, excellent features, nice design.
Cons: None so far.

Billed as smart, when actually...it's obnoxious. The digital features are mostly useless. If you did want to change up your grind, you have to consort the manual because for some reason, this thing wants grind for cups x time.

A smart grinder, would grind by weight. Not time or cups. A smart grinder, also would not dump grinds all over itself instead of dropping them in the provided cup. And finally, a smart grinder would not be so comically oversized and that damn loud. I mean come on, as big as the housing is, put a sound barrier in the thing.

One last bit. At this price point...I expect a glass hopper and storage container. Not plastic.

Don't buy.

UPDATE 2/4/19: I’ve been using this grinder for quite some time now on a daily basis and it still gets 5 stars from me. I clean my burrs after each pound of coffee. Maybe those with problems of locking up could be helped with this practice? My original review stated static wasn’t a problem. That review was only after a weeks usage. However one just can’t seem to get completely away from it. I have discovered if I leave the lid off the plastic ground catcher there is less to clean up and it doesn’t take away from my 5 stars!

ORIGINAL REVIEW: I didn't purchase here, but when I research an item before purchase, this is one of the places I come to read reviews. I've had this grinder a week and am pleased with its performance. I paired this grinder with a new coffee maker, OXO 9 Cup Barista Brain. I've been doing pour over for a couple years but, have grown tired of having to make individual cups throughout the day. I wanted something a little more automatic and with a thermal carafe. Thus, the reason for new equipment.

It has taken me a week to dial in the correct settings for the current beans I have which are a fresh French Roast. I normally weigh my beans before grinding and that ratio bean to water which gave me too strong a brew. I don't know if it was the grinder or the new coffee maker responsible and I'm guessing it's the combination of the two. I found with this new equipment, I do not have to use as many beans. I decided I was going to use the timing of the grind on this grinder rather than weighing each time.. One less step. I am happy to report that after a week of trial that I've dialed down to the perfect cup of coffee to my taste. I make a pot each day and drink it throughout the day with enough left over to take a cup to work in the evening.

I've not found static to be much of a problem. It's attractive sitting at my beverage station and couldn't be happier with my purchase. I can't vouch for longevity of the item but it's ability to grind a consistent batch of beans for my drip is spot on. I do not drink espresso, so cannot comment on the grinders ability to that or to grinding course enough for French Press. However, if you have a good drip maker that brews coffee at the right temp (and I highly recommend the OXO), you can't go wrong with this grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Impeller failed = to the trash can
reviews.reviewText: A lemon? It ground coffee well about 30 times and then the problems started. In the midst of grinding it would whir with a screaming sound. I had to take it apart to clean it every time I wanted to grind coffee. I checked online discussions and it seems that the impeller no longer works. (That dumps the ground coffee into the container.) Breville doesn't make a replacement part, but evidently somebody has designed one with his 3-D printer. That's not what I want to deal with, so it's now headed for the trash. I expect better quality for the money.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not built for the long haul
reviews.reviewText: I have had this machine for 4 years and liked it. However, it will no longer make an espresso grind. When set to any of the espresso settings, the machine grinds. Apparently some beans and denser than others and it is not powerful enough for denser beans. I contacted Breville and hopefully that can help me out. This was the best reviewed machine on amazon but it is not built to last. Sad sad day.

Best grinder ever! I've been through all of them, from the $19.99 stand up single pot to a $300 burr and everything in between. This one is so good I bought a backup just in case! Grinds very uniformly, many settings to customize your grind, and, most important of all, is easy to clean and works like brand new afterwards. I've been using it daily for over 2 years new and I still consider it one of my best investments in coffee and in kitchen appliances.

I am a French press user and bought this to replace an older grinder from another maker. It is a nice machine. Much quieter than my old one. Has a lot more features to fine tune the grind. Looks nice on the counter.

The big issue is getting a coarse grind. I started with the coarsest setting, out of the box. Too fine. I followed the instructions to change the default setting. I did it multiple times until it was at the highest (most coarse) setting. I couldn't see any change in the grind each time. And, at the end of all that have stopped using the machine and got a refund.
This is the only reason I gave it less than 5 stars.
If you use a finer grind, you'd love this machine.

reviews.reviewTitle: This bad boy is staying on the counter
reviews.reviewText:
We got this as a gift and have been using it for about a month. At first, I was skeptical-- counter space is at a premium in our San Francisco kitchen, and we joke that every appliance must serve three functions-- but after a month, we are hooked. This bad boy is staying on the counter.

I don't have anything smart to say beyond the fact that yes, you can taste a difference. Everyone probably knows that but I had my doubts. Depending on my mood, I make coffee in a Chemex and AeroPress, and stovetop espresso with a Bialetti Moka Express. You can taste the difference in all three. Andytown beans ground in this and made with AeroPress turned out to be the best cup of coffee I've had in my life. In San Francisco, that's saying something.

I bought this grinder in 2015 (about two years ago). We used it multiple times, daily, to fill the portafilter for each cup. Obviously that's more demanding on the machine than filling up a basket once every few days, but it also makes much better coffee to use freshly ground beans. Yesterday it finally gave up the ghost and stopped working. The amount of control we had over the grind and quantity was exceptional. It's also not too loud, which is nice when you have a couch covered with groggy supermodels who are working through their hang-overs.

I purchased my 820 from Williams Sonoma less than 90 days ago (i don't think it was available on Amazon at the time). It was amazing the, automatic dosing control and the grind were superb for my E61 group machine. It stopped working 3 days ago in the middle of preparing a normal shot. I was able to return it for a full refund, and thought about just replacing it on the spot with the same model, but was advised against it.

Herein lies the dilemma; there are few other pro-sumer models that provide the automatic features that the Breville 820 has, yet and still the build quality is in question. For example, The Rachillio Rocky is a solid grinder at $355, but is completely manual, and the next Rancillio model, with automatic dosing is around $900.

While the Breville worked, it was an amazing machine and value. I might wait and see if the built quality improves over time (since this model is new), however Breville has had a lot of practice with the previous automatic 800XL model and should have had these issues related to manufacturing defects worked out

This is a great grinder. It's an excellent pair for my Keurig. I've had it for a couple years now. Bought two - one for the office and one for the house. My wife loves it as well. After going through a number of refillable K-Cups, we settled on the Ekobrew Stainless Elite Cup of which we purchased two for each location. I'll take this any day over the pre-made K-Cups. It's actually amazing to watch the fat molecules in the cream get sucked into the coffee particles of the fresh made brew as it "creams up". The freshness of the coffee far outstrips any of the gut-rot you'd purchase at Starbucks, I'll never set foot in the place again.

This grinder is a thing of beauty. Took two tries to get the perfect grind for espresso (15), and espresso comes out nearly flawless. I looked at quite a few models before settling on this one and so glad I did! It has a good speed and not overly fast, not too noisy and love all the extras that come with it to suit my needs. Plus looks great and not too big or bulky on my counter. There is a warning that comes with this machine that it can overheat if used for a long time, so be warned to give it a breather in-between grinds to keep it running.

reviews.reviewTitle: Get the two year protection. You will need it!
reviews.reviewText:
Get the two year protection. You will need it. The warranty is one year and I have been lucky the machine made it mostly intact through one year. But a product of this price and a brand pretending to offer quality should last longer than one year. And no, not in my case...

A month after the warranty ran out it started to go downhill...We are now at a point where it will only grind one portion, irrespective of what it shows on the screen, and it does not take light roasts anymore. Shame sham shame Breville. Seems almost designed to break after a year...

If you want a grinder that works, hopefully, for a year and becomes a paperweight after that, buy this product. You won't be disappointed. If you want something that lasts longer; look elsewhere!

This product is loaded with plastic parts - gears, impellers, etc. - that wear out and break. Breville has made the decision to not sell any replacement parts so expect this to be a disposable appliance that will last most consumers a year or two at most.

reviews.reviewTitle: Fills my kitchen with the smell of burnt plastic
reviews.reviewText: I bought this grinder from another web site, but I'm reviewing it here. I love everything about the grinder, except for the smell of burnt plastic that it makes. One of the most important features of a grinder is to fill your kitchen with the wonderful smell of freshly ground coffee. Instead, it smells terrible. I've made about 7 pots of coffee, and it still smells like burnt plastic. It's time to return this grinder. :(

I don't have one but am thinking of getting one. For those who say it doesn't grind coarse enough for a French press, you do realize that the burrs are adjustable right?
"Adjustable Upper Burr: In addition to 60 separate grind settings, you can also remove the top burr to manually adjust the default settings, thus extending the grind range. This product did not work.

This thing is junk. Would never but again. Has trouble feeding. How am I supposed to get a consistent grind? Avoid!

reviews.reviewTitle: Great For Brew Methods requiring Fine to Medium Grind. Not for Coarse.
reviews.reviewText:
I exclusively brew Chemex. I am using the new Chemex Ottomatic. Even with adjusting the upper burr, I could not get a coarse grind to my liking.

The grinder had a lot to offer. It was easy to maintain. It was very easy to see and change settings. It produced virtually no mess. I found that it retained a fair bit of grounds.

I am giving it 4 stars, even though I returned it, because it produces really great finer to medium grind. I could see this being an ideal grinder for Hario V60 or even auto drip. But it did not fulfill my expectations at the coarser end. I returned the grinder to WS after one week of use, because of the grinder's inability to produce a suitably coarse grind.

UPDATE

I have returned to this grinder. I am impressed with how easy it is to take apart for routine maintenance. I am getting very good brews in my Chemex Ottomatic.
Easy to use and has worked consistently well for us for over 6 months since we got it. We make espresso about 4-5 times a week with it.

After 3 weeks of using and liking it....It;s going back.
The grind is actually great on medium grind. I use it for drip in my Technivorm. It seems reasonably quiet compared to my Baratza Encore which wore out after 3 years. Looks like a sturdy machine, less static than the Baratza but I'll hand grind for a while and save to trade up to the Baratza Preciso. I really liked the simplicity of the Encore....Off-On...that's it. I weigh my coffee so I don't need fancy timers, digital red outs and would never store coffee in the hopper. It is easy to program and use. Lots of pluses for a medium grind but WTF (please excuse, but I have a big problem with the worst part of the design)... A ONE FOOT CORD? REALLY? SORRY NO EXCUSE. CODE- Outlets are 4 feet apart in a (Modern) kitchen. Farther apart in older kitchens. EVERY APPLIANCE NEEDS A 2 FOOT CORD! I will NOT buy an extension cord for this poor design. It's going back. And I'll be purchasing a Baratza again. Baratza is Simpler to use, HARDER to take apart to clean, less to program, and I can plug it in where I want.

Bought this three years ago based on great customer reviews and internet evaluations. Works well when working, but requires a tremendous amount of cleaning maintenance to assure it remains working. Three years out, I'm in the market for a new grinder as the motor on this came to a screeching halt and died. If it requires that much cleaning to assure it runs to specification, yet over-powers the motor and dies anyway, I can't recommend this to anyone at all.
The grind, the flavor, the convenience: excellent.

Buyer Beware! Superb home use grinder until the gears start slipping and then you have to double the grind time to get the amount you need... But how long will that work before the gears give out entirely...? As for replacement parts... forget about it! The product line has an inherent design weakness in the gear material and if you look up which parts are available you will find the gear - part #130 has been discontinued! How can they ethically do that... Enjoy your future $200 paperweight while it is working :-(

REVIEW CORRECTION: my review details my experience with the BCG800XL model not the BCG820BSSXL... Tho I note the parts list for it is the same as the 800XL model :-(

UPDATE: after nursing this grinder along forever I am delighted to report that I recently bought and installed a new impeller for this grinder and this has restored it to its original fabulous functionality! Researched and designed by a fellow frustrated Breville owner... watch his excellent YouTube video "How to fix the Breville Smart Grinder Jamming Problem (BCG800XL Coffee Grinder)" for details.
Standard Disclaimer: I am not associated with the video presenter or Shapeways in any manner whatsoever.

Update: I'm about 4 1/2 months in with this grinder and it still works great. Through trial and error, I've found that the ideal grind size and time setting for two shots of Lavazza medium roast espresso beans is 21 grind size/16.8 seconds on the digital display. The grind setting is at the lower end of the display's espresso range (fineness decreases as the grind size increases). This setting delivers the precise amount of ground coffee required for two shots directly into the portafilter. I just have to tamp it down once and brew. I don't know how grind size and grind time might vary from one brand of beans to another.

Earlier: I chose this the Breville because: (1) I have two other Breville machines--a milk frother I bought several years ago, and the Duo-Temp Pro espresso maker, which I purchased in September 2018, and I've been very satisfied with them. (I haven't rated this grinder for durability because I've only had it a short time, but based on the quality and performance of the frother, I expect it and the Duo-Temp Pro espresso maker to hold up just as well); and (2) because I liked the idea of grinding just the right amount of beans directly into the portafilter. On that score, it works great.

Other machines have as many as 60 manual grind adjustments. The Breville's digital display has 58 grind settings, ranging from super dense for Turkish coffee, to very coarse for French press. The display makes grind adjustment easy for anyone. (Grinding for dummies?)

Amazing coffee grinder for fresh drip coffee everyday. It looks beautiful in my kitchen counter. Love the digital display for the grind setting that has a nice rotary knob like a volume knob on my radio. This grinder might be too slow for the espresso lover but for drip coffee, it is perfect for the price point of $200.00 dollars. Effective and beautiful! I really love grind holder on this breville grinder.
